110804739.review:
The game is designed to show the struggle and horrors of a civil war from a civilian perspective, and while it succeeds in showcasing it's anti-war message, it's also a game I don't think is much fun as a result. 

One of the biggest issues is just that the game refuses to teach you anything about how to play it, other than the movement and action system. There's no explanation for any of the mechanics or conditions other than your survivors constant whining for food, sleep, smokes, or medicine. You get flavor hints and prompts; no numbers. You can guess at what the game wants you to do, but often enough your best guess might just kill a run because that's not how the game wants you to play it.

The wounding system in particular is very catty. In most games, giving the character a rest and a bandage will see them healed up. In This War of Mine, you need daily bandages (almost impossible to keep up), keep them fed to the brim, let them rest in bed for days and nights, and sometimes they'll still get worse. 

Sickness in cold weather is similar. The game offers you a heater, which one might assume would protect against the cold if you give it wood. Nope. You need multiple heaters. You also need to fill them to the brim, because that makes them hotter. No, it doesn't matter where they're placed. None of this is explained, and you'll be wondering why your survivors are freezing despite having a heater right next to them. 

It's easy to have a survivor freeze to death overnight when healthy, while you struggle to upgrade and construct multiple heaters, because you hadn't planned to need all these heaters, AND, every location is mysteriously out of parts.

It's very hard to recover from a downward spiral if you don't go on the wiki and KNOW where to go and what to do before it starts, because the game just doesn't convey anything.

I think my biggest gripe is the inventory system. You're given a grid with some locked squares, implying you can upgrade your inventory somehow, so surely you just need a high enough crafting bench right? Maybe make a backpack? Once you get that, everything will go smoothly in your scavenging, right? You'll be abl eto make up for all the spent parts on upgraded workstations, right? Wrong. It's a trap. Most survivors will have 10 slots for life. Deal with it. And items just don't stack past a small handful or 1 per slot. The entire system will have you leaving more goodies than not, which feels disappointing, rather than fun or rewarding. This is what most often causes the downward spiral. You need too many different things all the time and can't bring them home. You'll often have to burn trips by sending in a scav with armor/guns/tools/bullets which leaves no room for taking things back.

I think a lot of players might feel inclined to defend TWoM simply because it's stated goal is to simulate the miserable and desperate struggle of a group of civilians in a warzone. Sure. It succeeds at that. The game does simulate a desperate struggle, but it does this by obfuscating its mechanics and simultaneously punishing you for not knowing them. My best recommendation would be to get an inventory mod or a noob mod and be prepared to read a lot of wiki pages anyhow so you know what you're doing. Even with all of that though, I can't say the game is much fun. Once you learn all the mechanics and map the game out in your head, you'll feel like there isn't much left to see or do.

110686499.review:
I don't know how I feel about this game. On one hand, it offers moments ranging from the heartfelt to the horrific. It reaffirms my desire to be a part of humanity while also presenting me with some of its worst elements.

HOWEVER, this part of the game is tacked onto a set of mechanics that just do *not* respect the player's time. 
As I get older, and responsibilities nudge my free time into a smaller and smaller corner of my life, I have to make the most of the time I have. In a well structured experience, the game works with the player to determine satisfying exit points. For example, I might feel the need to stop after playing an hour or two of an intense horror game, or after feeling the satisfaction of finishing a curated six hour experience. In contrast, This War of Mine leaves me feeling like time has hardly passed after sessions where morning turns to night. It sucks hours out of my life like an unpleasantly bureaucratic vampire.

I love games that take us into places other than fun. I love that this war of mine takes us into places of loss, of grief, of suffering. However, ideally this pain should be chained to the experience. Losing a survivor after 6 hours of gameplay today had me feel real existential pain. It didn't make me think about war and loss, it made me think of the two thirds of the previous 6 hours that were spent micromanaging agonisingly slow timers and waiting. I will never get that time back.

110648587.review:
Not a First Person Shooter, not a survival tycoon, but an [i] experience [/i]. The distinction is essential to the purpose of the game since without it, it is merely another FPS/survival game. I personally refunded a few crappy games to purchase this and I did not regret my decision one bit. If the game induces empathy and melancholy then congratulations, you played this correctly. 

The story of the game is based on the 1994 Balkans Conflict, particularly during the Siege of Sarajevo which lasted at least a year before broken and relief was sent to the people although in the game, the war would last around 30-60 days depending on the character set you start with.

Regarding the characters, barring one (Roman) they are civilians with different qualities, emotions, stories and strengths and you unlock more of their background story as the game progresses. You build your shelter in the day, you scavenge for supplies in the night.

The key to enjoying this game is not winning. Its surviving and as I've mentioned above, empathizing  with the soldiers, civilians, [b] even the thieves. [/b]

110546887.review:
I really enjoyed the game until the combat part came:
- I like the idea for the game
- I like the moral choices you are given
- I like the graphics - the sketchy effects are really nice
- The game has its atmosphere

But the game has lots of bugs which ruin the whole experience. The bugs work both ways: they can help you too much, rendering the game not challenging, or they can make your life miserable.

**The combat system is the worst aspect of this game.**
The character will often not react to your commands, just standing there, getting themselves killed. And you cannot save/load game at any time. So your character dies because the game decided not to listen to you, and then it saves the progress for you.

The game will also not teach/tell you when it's getting autosaved. If you think you've finished day in the game and decide to turn it off - oops, all day is lost, because it only saves at dawn. Try again.

Selecting characters works randomly. Sometimes, you click on a character and it gets selected. Sometimes you click on a character, and currently selected character goes to the location where you clicked. This hitbox problem seems to affect every interactive object.

You can basically win the game by going to 1 single location - the Garage. Trader's inventory gets replenished all the time, and once you traded with him, you can go to his basement to steal whatever you just traded in. And then repeat. Almost infinite items - you're limited only by your backpack capacity.
This "exploit" I noticed myself, but I read on a wiki about many more "exploits" like this.
It ruins the challenge.

There is no keyboard support in this game. You can't even look around with arrow keys.

The game does not remember my fullscreen setting - it always starts in windowed mode.

The game was made in Poland, yet the Polish localization is so bad (unnatural, mechanical), that I - being native Polish speaker - decided to play the game in English. Weird.
The English localization is perfect though.

The game begs for other improvements:
- Why can only 1 character go scavenging?
- Why does the character get tired if I finish scavenging in 1 hour?

No wonder the game is being sold so cheap - I suspect people would get frustrated if they paid more.
Well, I got frustrated enough to leave a comment.

With all the above there's no incentive for me to start another game.

If there was an option to save the game at any time (or at least if it'd autosave at dusk), I'd just use it to neutralize these combat issues. But there isn't.

110443068.review:
I've played this game for a number of years on PS4 and PC. I love the atmosphere of the game and game play overall. The idea of the game is to make all the survivors outlast the Winter and the War. You will have to  scavenge, trade and maybe steal to get what you need to survive.

You can play the story lines already created for you, or customize your own with select characters. All characters have a skill to benefit survival. The survivors all live in a home you must upgrade with furnishings to have a place to sleep and eat. There are lots of piles of mess to go through to find building materials off the bat.

Your people have to sleep/guard/scavenge at night. You carefully pick what would work best according to what you need to go find and the survivor's moods. Some are too tired or sick to go out or guard so be wary.
Scavenging can be dangerous so eventually, you'll need to make or find weapons and upgrade your workshops to make the necessary equipment. 

If you can make it to the end of the game with all your original survivors, you know you were successful. This game is so fun, not too repetitive and the random events keep it interesting. This game can be difficult if you're too strategic with your plan to survive.

110399957.review: Lo primero he de decir que nunca había jugado a ningún juego de supervivencia de este tipo antes, y vaya sorpresa, es el juego que siempre quise. Hace unos años deseaba encontrar un juego survival aunque fuese en 2D o incluso sin entorno gráfico, solo rol puro, y mi error fue buscarlo en el ámbito de juego móvil, y no encontré más que aburridísimos juegos por turnos y sin el más mínimo interés. Este juego es todo lo contrario, es un RPG de rol en 2D a tiempo real, es súper realista, hasta un punto en que me he llegado a sentir mal por robar en al casa de unos pensionistas que no hacían nada mientras les desvalijaba, solo hablarme, está muy bien hecho. Tiene un sistema de bases y puntos a los que puedes ir de noche durante ciertas horas para saquear y conseguir provisiones, mientras en tu base fabricas lo que necesites, descansas, te alimentas, te tratas o incluso conversas con alguien si estás triste. Es un juego completísimo y que personalmente me abre la puerta a un nuevo género que no había experimentado antes y que seguro que no me decepcionará. Para terminar recomendar mucho las historias, son pequeños DLCs muy baratos que te ponen en la piel de unos supervivientes y pasan por determinadas situaciones, la toma de decisiones es absoluta, permitiéndote matar a todo NPC que encuentres fuera de tu refugio, o robar a tus aliados, mil posibilidades y el juego te escucha y reacciona a ellas, merece mucho la pena y te aseguran horas de diversión.

110359313.review:
I was glad. Things were going quite well for my four survivors. It was around Day 27. They had just fixed a broken guitar and a little bit before the nightfall Katia was playing the guitar and Kalina was listening to her play and sang(?). I thought it was heartwarming.

Then it was time to send Katia to scavenge. I chose St. Mary's Church and wasn't too worried, because I thought it would be relatively safe. There wasn't much to find though and then I saw a man and made Katia sneak a little bit closer, so that I could hear what the man was mumbling. I hid Katia and waited. I figured the man wasn't interesting and thought it would be better to leave, and just when Katia stepped out of her hiding spot the man found what he had been looking for, turned around and spotted Katia.

He had a gun. Katia didn't have any weapons. I think he shot Katia or then I just decided it was best to flee, as he approached Katia threateningly, and after that he started shooting. I wish I had guided Katia to a different route, but I didn't. She started to climb the ladders and was shot to death. I was shocked.

In the morning, seeing my other survivors sad, especially little Kalina, was heartbreaking. Everything had seemed to go well and now it was just a distant memory. I had lost my bargainer and it was harder to play with only two adults. I knew I had made mistakes and I cursed my timing, maybe Katia would have survived if I had waited longer, maybe I could have hidden her somewhere if I had guided her to a different route. Pavle or Bruno said something like "she was just here and now she isn't" and that's exactly how I felt. It was sad and it gives me shivers.

I didn't dare to return to St. Mary's Church, but I want to explore it when I start a new game. The other three survived.

Es un juego bastante entretenido con unas mecánicas difíciles y una idea bastante interesante. En general, creo que This War of Mine es un título que transmite muy bien el mensaje que quiere enviar y lo hace con un gameplay desafiante a la par que coherente consigo mismo.
Respecto al juego, sobre todo al principio, lo vas a pasar mal. Muchas recetas no te las sabes, acumularás objetos inútiles y demás, pero una vez le pillas el tranquillo todo es mucho más fácil y entretenido.

Como puntos positivos, destacaría que el juego tiene un buen apartado visual que va acorde a la estética general, la música está bien y las distintas situaciones en las que te pone son desafiantes. Puedes jugar varias veces una partida y según con qué personajes empieces será muy distinto.
Empecé probando al equipo más sencillo, el cual tiene a Pavle (corre, pero no es muy importante), Marko (explora mejor por las noches) y Bruno (las recetas cuestan menos) y hace que una run sea extremadamente fácil. Pero luego probé a jugar con Christo (padre) e Iskra (hija) y el desafío fue bastante más interesante.

Finalmente, el DLC merece la pena, ya que añade el modo Historias, donde es el mismo juego, pero dirigido por una historia que añade nuevas mecánicas (conversaciones de historia) y te fuerza a hacer ciertas misiones especiales que desembocan en varios desenlaces.

Entre las cosas malas que destacaría del juego es que:
- a veces es muy obtuso (incluso cuando sabes todo del juego)
- tiene algunos bugs molestos (aunque poco relevantes) si fuerzas ciertas cosas (y como es un juego antiguo no lo van a arreglar) 
- el juego te fuerza demasiado a ser buena persona. Me gustaría un poco más de libertad donde pudiésemos hacer ciertas cosas con algunos personajes, ya que todos se deprimen cuando haces algo éticamente cuestionable. Pero siendo sincero, en alguna run me gustaría probar otras cosas y que el juego no te penalice tanto por decidir matar a un tío, o al robar a cierta gente, es decir, que nos dé algo más de libertad para probar cosas.

PD: Conseguir todos los logros es un infierno. Algunos logros está bugeados y no aparecen cuando deben.

108924732.review: I heard of this game way back when it first came out, I watched the first part of a few playthroughs a few times, but that was it. Fast forward to late 2021, I remember this game exists, it's on sale, I buy it. After having beaten the base game, and two of the story DLCS, I'd say that the game is pretty fun. You manage resources such as food, medicines, crafting materials, and weapons/ammo/tools. You gotta feed your peeps, and scavenge sites in the night. Sometimes those sites have people who you gotta kill, or sneak around as you steal from them. It's a pretty interesting story of desperation and survival to play through. There are also various different survivors who you can get, who all have different specialties, such as a cook who can make food for slightly less resources, or the skilled scavenger who has the most scavenging slots for items, or a guitar player, who can play the guitar you can repair, and make people and herself happier. It's a good game overall.

108126242.review:
I think this is an overrated game. It's an OK 7/10 game to me.  I played through the main game twice. Other time with Final Cut team.

If in Cannon Fodder war had "never been so much fun", in This war of mine war has never been so much a chore. 
The other part of the gameplay is an optimization management game keeping your people alive. Its not too hard if you keep your wits in it. Spare items and food, stay hungry but alive and hanging in there and you'll be ok. Perhaps I haven't seen enough sides of the game as I was all the time kind of sailing through with no big issues?

The other part of gameplay is about going out of your safehouse in nighttime to collect items in maps or trade stuff with people. Sneaking around is sometimes fun and tense, but sometimes the opponents just see you from weird angles. Combat is super dangerous and clunky but you can mostly avoid it because you find enough items by trading and taking stuff lying around.

People tell about "gutwrenching and touching stories". But I think the characters you have are relatively shallow. In the level of "This one can cook", "This one smokes", "This dude is ok with stealing from others, this dude isn't". "This dude met his wife while on the job as fireman", "This one is pregnant and now only cares about her baby".. Wow thats deep.

Also game has few bugs which don't seem like they're going to get fixed. For example, a group of thugs had killed a priest and taken over a church so I whacked one of the guys and also took some of their stuff. It was considered "stealing". Later I ended up killing all the bandits there and taking more of their stuff. My people are "worried that how will the poor people there now make it after I stole their stuff".... 
NEWSFLASH, they were evil people trying to shoot me and they are dead now. 
So I don't think they mind anymore.

All in all, get this on sale and try it out, perhaps you like. But I cannot "recommend" a game when its gameplay is quite limited and ultimately relatively easy.

If you want tips:
- Make moonshine, you can get assault rifles by day 3 by trading it to soldiers
- Make a hatchet, chop stuff to pieces to get free fuel
- Board up your safehouse asap
- Sleep on daytime
- Trading is more useful than self suffiency

107903212.review:
I have no idea why it took so long for me to pick  up and play this game. I fear picking it up again due to how pulled into it I can get. 

The motif of the game is gorgeous and raw. Its atmosphere is consistent and it speaks its purpose from start to finish. There is a message, experience, and a depth that really come with the game that is so rare. Aesthetics. Music. Writing. Challenge. This War of Mine really has it all.

The systems are easy enough to get. Play a few rounds and you should have it down. 

A few things I learned. Game saves after each night of "scavenging". If something bad happens, alt tab and force quit the game to prevent it. Helps while learning, but really can trivialize parts of the game. Still, worth knowing while you are surfing that learning curve.

The whole vibe of the game "War is Hell", is just communicated so beautifully in a captivating and top notch game. I really enjoyed it. Hats off to the developers.

107838160.review:
This War of Mine is a refreshing take on the flood of military style shooters that make up most of my Steam profile. It is told from a side-scrolling perspective where you have to learn how to support your fellow survivors against enemy scavengers, the cold, and worst of all, hunger itself. The game is not supposed to be fun on a constant basis. It can be frustrating at times and due to its rogue-like nature, you will not get a perfect run on the first try. The standout feature of This War of Mine is its ability to balance between being a decent survival game while illustrating the real-life consequences of war.

10/10 will get depressed again

107410397.review: Talking about story, this game is so simple yet so intricate and detailed in its design. Essentially, you are trying to survive through an all out war, where everyone attacks each other, there are shortages in food and resources and harsh changes in temperature and weather. The main goal is to survive, scavenge and protect your dwellers from extinction. However, once you start playing, you realise how much more this game really is. You play through each day, planning out what to build, who to feed and organising what you need for the forthcoming night of scavenging, where it's do or die. The character's are all sentient to each others actions, with the ability to feel empathy, become depressed or content/elated at another's decision. Stacked with intricate development and pristine graphic quality, if you want to try something new, I recommend this game for you.

I would deffiently recommend you to buy the game for that 20$ or if you want then wait for a sale.

There is a community side of this game where you can create your own characters, stories and such,
that is a very good experience too.
Last but not least there is a survival mode where you get a few characters and you'll have to help them survive the war.
There are also some side quests that you can decide to complete or not
FE: 2 young siblings come to your shelter and ask for help because their mother is dying.. 
If you help them you'll have to give them medicines that you would probably have to use later.
If you choose not to help them you don't lose nothing but the kids lose their mother
You might say that It's just a game and no one cares.. but when you play the game you'll know
that It's not that easy.

This game deffinetly worths It's price 9/10

107215614.review:
It took quite a few attempts for this to click with me...

It's bleak and gruelling, as you try to figure out what you're doing, but upon completion I have to say it's a really immersive, emotionally affecting, strategic survival/resource management platformer, which while not perfect, has a great deal to offer, the likes of which are few and far between.

As the game days go steadily by you become strangely attached to your people, such that any death, accident or illness feels genuinely urgent and tragic. As with 11-bit Studio's later masterpiece, Frostpunk, the early game punishes you mercilessly for getting a poor start, and there will come a point, if you're careful, where you can sit back, and take it easy. It's fail hard or win hard.

As the credits roll with Polaroids of the major events of your play-through, you realise what a fucking Hero Boris was, for the time he saved that girl in the abandoned bakery, and for the time he snuffed it in the siege of St. Mary's church, after which you don your helmet, tactical vest, automatic rifle, and avenge his honour. 

That's what this game will do to you. Just be prepared to take your time to learn the game, don't take unnecessary risks, and always keep a stash of 'high-quality roll-ups'.

 After all, in modern war, you will die like a dog for no good reason.

107134482.review:
This game has been on my "to play" list for many years, alas, I believe I've come to the party a tad late. Back in 2014, when this game was released, the survival genre was in the middle of its renaissance. Games like Subnautica, Rust, Don't Starve, and Day Z, had all been released and were receiving great praise. Unfortunately, the variety of titles available at the time has relegated This War of Mine to the proverbial back seat. Now, 7 years later, is this game still good? 

Well... yes and no. 

If you love survival games, then yes, This War of Mine is for you; it's a paragon of the survival genre with a few unique mechanics that bring moments of tension and excitement. Unfortunately for me, these moments are too few and far between with the game relying too heavily on the tiresome crafting mechanics. So if you are returning to the survival genre, after a period of respite, expecting to re-ignite your love, then no, this game is not for you. Maybe in another 5 to 10 years, but not now.

Be selective with what you scavenge, you can come back for things later that arn't needed right away (they don't disappear).  This game may be morbid for some, but its amazing and although seems simplistic you sure can clock up the hours.

106231216.review: This game is grim, but very well made and tells some fantastic stories. I have already spend quite a few hours in the game and this will properly not be my last time coming back to it. There is a really nice and slow progression system, where you are out and gather materials every night and can them use them during the day, while also trying to keep your people warm and full. You really do have to make some questionable choices at the end a game sometimes, to have a chance to survive, that I most of the time have not really been that proud of. Overall a very enjoyable game, but it can get a bit repetitive, as there are only a few different homes and a limited number of places to go to, but there are a few different events at each place and not all places are available at each playthough.

106229231.review:
The game barely lives up to what it offers. 
The characters feel bland and boring, the mechanics are outdated and offer no engagement, there's no tutorial to understand how things work, even though most of them are simple enough to be figured out in the first few minutes of playing.
The main problem with the game is how empty it is. The player will spend the most part of its day doing nothing, waiting for the night to come and actually be able to scavenge some supplies. However the incredibly small inventory spaces of the characters can't carry much and so many times you'll barely manage to get back home with enough to get by despite the huge loads of stuff available in the different locations.
Once you've actually brought back enough materials to get by, if you haven't been raided during the night, you can usually do one (1) thing before you run out of material. Stockpiling is near impossible  again because of the small inventory spaces that are also fixed, there's no way to improve them through equipment or consumables.
Narratively speaking, the game is passable. It tells a few stories that are almost enjoyable and the characters within them act like you'd expect in a war. However in game some characters say contradictory lines or suffer sudden changes in morality for no reason, adding to the overall sense of incomplete work that was released before working out the kinks to make it more engaging.
I tried to give it ample opportunities, hence my playtime, but it never got interesting enough to keep me hooked. Overall a waste of time, there are many better options to experience these kind of management games.

106180646.review: Engrossing logistics/resource management challenge while testing your personal moral code and empathy. Many times I have lost a character through depression, starvation, sickness or violence (usually a combination of all afflictions) and I still feel remorse over how they died months later. If you don't feel empathy for the characters and their situation, then this is probably not a good game for you. Combat is brutal and quick--no armor or health buffs to speak of and almost always a path to quick character death while also degrading your team. Excellent simulation of why war is horrific and to be avoided. Not for F'boys looking for another combat sim or shooter.

106135970.review:
This War of Mine es excelente.

Un juego con todas las letras. Ambiente logrado gracias al soundtrack y al arte que maneja. Los personajes se sienten reales cada uno con su personalidad y su propia historia y guerra que los hacen sentir únicos, ver como se manejan con los problemas que se presentan y como dialogan entre ellos cuando están deprimidos es algo de ver.
Los problemas que se presentan y las decisiones difíciles que se toman son crudos y lo más probable es que te vas a arrepentir de lo que tengas que eligir pero es parte de sobrevivir la guerra.
El mundo que construyeron al rededor de la guerra se siente vivo... O muerto... Depresivo, se siente la tensión y la pena que cada uno vive y como cada casa es un mundo distintos, desde los viejos que solamente que te vayas sin hacer daño hasta la gente que solamente por verte por su territorio va a abrir fuego, a todo esto una cosa que no pensé que sucedería es el hecho de ponerme tenso en mi primera persecución, logro ponerme nervioso y querer salir por patas de ese lugar pero por suerte tenía un arma y logre hacerles frente pero eso no quita lo que me hizo sentir, aquel peligro que me pedía salir disparado hacía la salida cuando escuche: "¡Atrapen a esa zorra!". 

El juego es magnifico como ya dije anteriormente pero no es algo perfecto, hay situaciones muy molestas que casi me hacen dejar el juego, ya que te intentan poner tensión pero termina siendo molesto tener a todos los refugiados heridos y que te roben más de lo que podas obtener por más que este el refugio asegurado al máximo y todos armados. Otro evento que siento que llego tarde en mi partida es el invierno, llego en un momento en el que ya había superado todos los saqueos y estaba bastante bien en mi partida y no logre sentir un peligro ni nada, solamente tuve que construir la chimenea y se acabo pero a lo mejor si lo re juego sea un reto aún mayor el invierno. 

¿Recomiendo This War Of Mine? Lo recomiendo ampliamente, con descuento aún más como es obvio pero el precio esta bien para la calidad que te ofrece este juego.

105903943.review:
I got back into this game a couple weeks back after not playing it much more after release. I'm not quite sure when I bought it, but around the time it came out i was still a kid in his mid teens. Played for a couple hours then quit because in all honesty I was complete trash at the game.

But coming back to it recently I found that being trash at the game is sort of part of the experience. In a good way, don't get me wrong. A fantastic way even. Your people will go through tons of struggles and hardships and you'll have to make important choices on what to focus on to keep people alive. Whether it be food, heating, general comfort, hell the game even takes into account psychological aspects where depending on your character, if they see or do something that would negatively impact a normal persons mental state, they can have full on anxiety attacks and such. Which you can treat over time by talking to them, or resort to cigarettes and booze to numb the pain... and then possibly get addicted to either of them.

I wish more games took their choices to the level that this game does. The phrase "choices matter" is an understatement here, and they don't always make it super obvious that you have a choice in some spots too. At which I'll say, sometimes if you see something messed up happening, think to yourself and wonder what the right thing to do would be, and if you have the balls to actually do it. As well as think about how it might negatively or positively effect your characters morale.

4$ is an absolute steal for this game and I sort of pray that something similar is in the works because I'd love to see a game like this be a bit bigger with more statuses and effects to manage. And to top all of that off, I noticed the sale and was recommending the game to a friend and went to buy the dlc. One of their DLC is pretty much just an opportunity to give a donation to charity. There are a lot of messed up situations in this game regarding children, and the fact that the developers even include that deserves a mad amount of respect.

The gameplay alone has a hell of a lot to enjoy. There's a strategic element to managing your time, your resources and your people, trading and scavenging, choosing infrastructure to build and maximising your opportunities. It's great fun.
However what really sets this game apart is the overall atmosphere of desperation and hard choices, it has moments of hope and tenderness set against an immensely bleak backdrop. Rarely does a game make me feel so anxious and conflicted. It's a real work of art in the true sense of invoking strong emotions in its audience, if you allow yourself to be drawn in you'll be living a nightmare in no time.

105491679.review:
This is a game that I have fallen in love with in a similar way I did with The Last of Us. IT has that gritty, hopeless theme and such a beautifully haunting art-style that adds so much to it. For me (not sure if it's the same for everyone when you first start) I started out with two survivors/dwellers as a father and daughter low and behold there are like 6-8 other groups you can play as (which I discovered when I accidentally killed one of mine).
 
This is a game where the mechanics are simple but you really figure it all out for yourself. How to balance the needs of your people, with needing to find food or materials and keeping other people out, your morals even. It really is an interesting take on that whole theme of just trying to keep hope alive in the worst sort of situations - well depending on how you play.

So far anyway, I have enjoyed my time with the game and finding out more about my people and trying desperately to keep them all alive.

105483976.review: Something you've not really seen games do before, a true "survival" game and one that tries its best to counteract the usual video game wartime power fantasy. Some bits show their age these days, and it doesn't *fully* get away from that pull of letting you grab a gun and rambo your way through something, but the whole package is just an incredible ethos I haven't got out of anything else. You are made to feel like survival is barely at your fingertips every step of the way, deciding heavily on how your respond to arbitrary changes made by actors operating way beyond your level. You aren't the RTS godhand, nor the action RPG protagonist, you're living the life of one NPC who's just trying to not die of cholera in the background. And those survival mechanics actually work, and are actually really engaging.

104949523.review: I've had a lot of fun playing this game, mixed with the sense of despair and horror that you find with the random events you can see in the main game and expansion stories. While initially a little tricky with the main game to get an understanding of what you need to do to survive the full duration of the siege, by your third time around you'll have a good grasp of the game mechanics to scavenge, fight and absolutely run for your life to survive when the time comes. This War of Mine doesn't pull any punches with how savage a modern day war siege can be and you can choose to be just as savage or try to maintain some humanity: the multiple endings of the game are connected to these decisions. In the side stories, compared to the main game they're a little weaker in that they are more linear with their progression but they are just as solid with their narrative. Overall this is an excellent game and well worth looking at for the survival management and strong story.

104521624.review:
This war of mine is a 2D game, its kinda side scrolling type of the game, but on the other hand it is made very intuitive, it has survival/crafting part of the game. The game is divided into 2 parts. 1st part is day, when you can go around house, build things, eat, rest or heal your survivors, trade if a trader comes around, or maybe help neighbours in some random encounter. 

The second part of the game is at night time, when you can choose one of your survivors and go out into town scavenging. There is a lot of different things, building materials, wood for heating, food, bullets, herbals, medicine and more. Your scavenger has limited space in his backpack, so I always chose the survivor that can carry the most items to go into scavenging missions.

First few locations for scavenging are easy, and you will make a lot of it. But as game moves towards mid-game, scavenging missions become harder, enemies carry weapons, and patrol around locations, and it is really not easy to survive. And game is kinda rogue-like, and once you fuck up, there is no turning back, you need to start the game anew.

I didn't manage to finish this game, but it is very addictive, and it made me start over more than 30 times with different survivors and different strategies. Every path and strategy you take has upsides and downsides to it, so you must choose carefully to make optimum profit out of everything.

There is also this atmosphere of desperation in the air all the time, and music is depressing accordingly. But when you have a sofa, the fire is burning and it is warm, and nobody is hungry, you can see survivors sit on the sofa, read a book and look kinda satisfied, so it makes you happy too. Progress in game is slow, but if you can every night bring maximum load of scavenged items, it will be a steady progress.

Excellent game, excellent idea, unique in game play, great atmosphere. I can only recommend it.

Add to that the somber music and desolate settings in which the game take place in, has a combination of hope and tension which affects the player. The altering game play styles with time management requirement for both day and night and the interdependence on how you carry them out affects your progress throughout the game. 104203244.review:
It would be huge if my characters could interact with each other in literally any fashion, rather than ignoring each other like mismatched college roommates. I'm not asking for BioWare-level banter or The Sims: Sarajevo Edition, but just the ability for survivors to chit-chat with each other would go a long way towards me perceiving these people as more than dolls in an usually grim dollhouse (it would also give me something to do for the 7 hours I have left after the day's chores of "listen to the radio" and "cook rat stew" are complete). It would also add some replayability: What happens when an elementary school principal, a militia deserter, and this country's equivalent of Anthony Bourdain have to survive together? I get that the developers don't want hijinks to get in the way of their very serious message, but I'm pretty sure human relationships don't cease to exist in wartime. If you want to tell a meaningful story, it helps to give me reason to care about these people.

As you can see, I have A LOT of hours in this game. I obviously find the core gameplay loop enjoyable (for what it's worth, it's a great "watching TV at the same time" game once you know the systems). But for a game whose marketing materials show people hugging, crying, having feelings, etc., that aspect of storytelling is bizarrely missing from the final product.

102959864.review: Well, I have only played 5 hours and restarted the game once. The concept is great, but with a huge flaw as far as I have seen - You can mostly scavange / loot items from other "people" in the city, with subsequent anguish and mental despair for your characters. This seems to be more or less unavoidable - Conflict is basically a part of the game and you will not be able to play this game "fair" if you are to succeed. This is maybe a part of the war, but I don't believe it is a necessity of war, where co-op is the key for long-term survival. So by doing the game-play narrowly in this direction, you can't really "win". You will always lose, even if you temporarily win. Some items that is a all out necessity is crucially hard to come by, even though in real life, it doesn't seem to be that big of an issue - for example bandages. There are so many other ways to make bandages, it is not really a difficult item in real life. Food is. I wished there were indicators, showing HOW tired, HOW hungry, HOW depressed they are, and what kind of things they need. For example, depression and sadness seems to be rampant, but no real solution to how to overcome this, even though I had both food, beds, sofa, radio and books. My guys were just not happy! The interface is ok, but overly simplified, few metrics as described, and more places to scavange where you actually don't steal from other people!

102798485.review:
Lackluster verisimilitude undercuts what's good about this game. Characters lament not knowing where their next meal will come from while tending to the garden and help neighbours to the hospital only to return with their own wounds untreated. Cumulatively, this takes away from the sense that you're sharing a harrowing experience with your survivors as much as you are simply playing a game, fulfilling the mechanical needs of their meters. It seems to occupy an unfortunate middle ground of characterization, where the characters aren't blank enough slates that a personality can be suggested purely by their mechanical abilities but also the dialogue and flavour-text aren't strong enough that their crafted personalities are endearing.

I think games should allow for moments that are, in a classical sense, awesome. These moments are generally where the written narrative and the emergent ludonarrative suddenly interlock in a beautiful, transcendent whole. The AI of an enemy in XCOM 2 causing it to attack a soldier with a psychic shield for multiple turns, allowing them to have a drawn out energy-blade duel; the moment in Spec Ops: The Line when you choose how you respond to the lynch mob that just removed of one of your NPC helpers from play; Sans' judgement in Undertale. I found but one moment that even approached that in War of Mine, when a newcomer to my house was kind to my little girl character and was able to offer her a healing item since *he* was healthy enough to do a scavenging run instead of the other--injured--adults. It was touching, and fulfilling--but fleeting. And, for some reason, not what the game was build around or seemingly designed to reliably reproduce.

Sure, one can argue that the game is about feeling bad, not about awesome moments. But I would argue that if you're not being made to feel awesomely sad, you're not sad. You're merely recognizing that the aesthetics of the game are demanding sadness. That's the thing to say about a game like War of Mine because the alternative opens one up to accusations of sociopathy. Ah yes, when small sprites I'd told were old people on my screen said 'please don't!' as I took their digital food tokens, I was inflicted with much sympathy. I ace all my Voight-Kampffs! But the fact of the matter is that striking deep at real core emotions requires better design than what's on display here.

102592657.review:
Basic premise is that you organise a group of refugees who've lost everything and are living in a bombed out house in a city warzone, all you have to do is keep them alive, scavange for what you need and just stay alive.

Where this game scores is not necessarily the technical issues but the characterisation. The individuals you look after are trying to deal with both the physical and mental issues of living in a warzone, hungry and tired and trying to come to terms with why they have to suffer when they never asked to be involved in a war they never started. It's heartbreaking to keep trying so hard and still seeing the people suffer, the hardest one for me was the one that starts off with a lone father and his daughter. It was hard to see how much stress and mental anguish the child suffered while the parent just muddled through. When another adult appeared you find yourself very suspicious of their motives, you have to decide if you're going to trust another adult to enter the group. Very clever way to play emotional games with you.

Yes, there are some technical things that could be improved, placing objects you made such as chairs and stoves can be a pain as you only have so much space and only allowed one type of object in a room at anytime. However it's not really about the technical prowess of the game, it's how it plays on your emotions and empathy for the suffering of other human beings.

It was very odd to play a game, they're just sprites but I really cared about the people especially the children, every time they wanted a hug or sat down and just cried, you felt you had to do something. So you're not only having to concern yourself with finding food, raw materials but also have to find ways to keep the character's morale going too.

The soundtrack is amazing, I paid extra to download that from Steam as MP3 and now have it on my permanently "quiet tracks playlist", incredible work there.

If you're not easily moved by a game's ability to tug at your emotions, you'll probably find this quite boring as it's really just a basic survival game at heart but if you're the kind of person who invests into a game's characters during game play then be prepared for a struggle to not give up on them and spend hours fighting to keep them alive, happy and healthy, I felt emotionally drained after a few hours of playing and needed time to calm down and cheer myself up.

102570572.review: One of the few games that gets at or reveals the true nature and actual reality of war, and for that one of the few games that draws a rare kind of respect. How it is such premeditated slaughter and bloodshed has became so often glorified, how such ill use of finite worldly materials that could've at another angle or in another light been used toward constructions for mutual benefit of the parties has confused me for years and forever will. What is the mechanism of humanity that results in such a narrowing of vision and purpose. Perhaps the same things that leads people to extinguish their environments gradually over time so throwing them into scarcity and panic. There must be answers to these questions.

101582621.review:
I know this game is an indie darling, but its got a lot of problems.

The gameplay in theory is good, the base building is okay I guess. I wish I had more places to put things so I could have more than one work station/chair/whatever per room. I also really wish the characters had more idle animations or actually did stuff like reading, sweeping or something. Also while you can board up some holes and recycle some furniture you can't ever seal the whole base off, which gets really annoying when the characters are complaining about snow and you just sit there like "WHY CAN'T I SEAL THESE BROKEN WINDOWS!?" 
The night scavenging is actually really good, combat is tense and difficult but it is possible to survive it if your careful. Stealth is very tense, mostly because of the top notch sound work and I love it! Some people might dislike the strict time limit that scavenging puts you under and I agree its far too short. But over all its a good mechanic and the level design is pretty solid, though the ai is... Bad. 

Unarmed goons will rush you even if you have a loaded assault rifle and a full suit of body armour. If you kill a sentry or any NPC really, the others don't change their patrol paths if you return or try to replace their lookouts. If a guy spawns on the third floor, he will stay there until you do something to lure him down. Then he will go right back to where he was if he didn't see you. Their movements are also quite predictable which I don't really mind, it does make stealth kills very easy but it's not the worst thing. I really wish the game would react more to you're scavenging or raiding. Instead every single location is heavily scripted which makes them loose any replay value pretty fast. 

When it comes to crafting the game tries to keep it "realistic" you're not going to craft a machine gun from nothing, or get medieval with a bow and arrow like this is minecraft. But it does have its share of nonsense, why do I need a filter to make Moonshine if the only ingredients are sugar and CLEAN water? Why do I need a filter for rain water, can't I just boil it? It's not the worst ever but I'm not above nitpicking moon logic in a game that wants to sell me a realistic war story.

I can't think of a good segway so lets talk about characters.
Each character has a unique ability which range from "unclear" to "worthless" and "game breaking cheese"
For an example, Pavle is just flat out faster at running than everyone. Not really that helpful is it.
But what do you do with a skill like "Good with kids"? 
Then there's Roman who has the game breaking "Combat trained" which means he can one shot melee, feels no guilt over murdering people by the dozens, and has way better aim and reloading speed.
Then there's Marko and his "Good cooking" which means his Moonshine takes half as many supplies to make but is worth just as much. No wonder they only let you carry one bottle per stack because Marko is the king of barter town. Combine him with Katia's "bartering skills" and you can buy basically anything. 

Each character can and will develop status effects as you play. A lot of which are at best unclear or at worst designed to just make you waste resources.
For example, still hungry means nothing. Don't waste food making sure everyone is stuffed unless they've got a status effect like wounded or depressed.
Same thing goes for slightly wounded. Just give them rest and regular food, don't bother filling their belly or giving them bandages.

However some statuses are just stupid. 
Depressed, Sad and Broken are dumb.
I don't want the game to TELL me how my character's feel. Especially because what triggers the statuses is basically "random". (In the sense they are so heavily scripted or character dependant it becomes impossible to find a pattern)
For example, robbing this one specific old couple will make who ever does it sad.
But robbing other random survivors? No emotional penalty unless you fail an invisible dice roll.
Killing random survivors is a great way to make your character depressed, but if the survivor is classed as a bandit (something you could only find out through wikipedia) then murder away! Who cares if they beg for mercy! Club 'em to death! Shoot them! Slit their throats when they ain't lookin! Their bandits! They have no souls!

The game wants to have its moral cake and eat it too. This is some Spec Ops the Line bullshit where the game just gets really judgy on you for no good reason. 
Staying with that tangent for a moment and veering close to spoilers. The endings are dumb. 
Each character has 6: Death, Suicide, Leaving, Karma, Sad and Good.
Death and Suicide should be obvious.
Leaving means they left the party for whatever reason.
"Karma" happens when you survive till the cease fire or escape the city but kill too many people or steal too much. 
"Sad" happens when you do the same but you didn't steal enough or kill enough to get the Karma ending but you ALSO didn't do enough random side objectives to get the "Good" ending.
Good happens when you don't steal, don't kill, and give away free supplies whenever the game asks you to. 
Again the game is very judgemental, I wish that each character had fewer endings with more detail instead of stretching them to fill a bunch of arbitrary moral classifications. 

Also addictions, addictions are dumb. 
Some characters will suffer a mood penalty (making them more likely to become Sad, Depressed or Broken whenever the appropriate roll is made) if they don't get their one pure water and cup of coffee or 3 smokes a day. 
Also you can pound Moonshine back like its water and they will never get addicted which I think is funny for some reason. The game wants to tackle some very serious issues but doesn't want to look at maladaptive coping mechanisms. 
I wish I could use coffee or cigarettes to boost my character's morale, at the risk of them becoming addicted or having bad side effects instead of it just being an automatic thing decided on generation. Or at least make them random instead of fixed.

When it comes to taking care of your survivors, some actions are basically pointless.
For example building chairs does nothing, even if you have books characters will never read. They'll just sit around and do nothing. I know just HAVING them supposedly provides positive morale but the game doesn't give you any feed back on how much morale (if any) is gained from having a comfy house. Just cheap uninspired flavour text. 
Cooking is also pretty worthless sine it consumes more resources than just eating canned food or eating raw food twice. (Unless you have Bruno then cooking actually pays some return on investment) If you wanna play on GG-EZ mode just avoid eating all together until the second day of "Very Hungry" status. 

Also, I know part of the profits for every copy of this game go to/went to charity. But that doesn't justify rough experience like this. If you care that much about charity, donate to them directly. 

I do admit, I enjoy This War of Mine. But I don't think cackling with glee when Marko beats 3 gunmen to death with a shovel is the kind of enjoyment the devs want me to be having. 
Like I said its got some flaws, but the gameplay is challenging and exploitable enough to keep me going on that a lone. 
And I fully admit most of the flaws can be fixed with mods, but a review should be about what a game IS not what it CAN become if you bolt the right fan addons to it. Get it on sale, if you don't like it refund it.

101462797.review:
[h1][100% Completion Review][/h1]

[b]Outline:[/b] I'm not even sure where to start with this one. This is my second time 100%ing the game as I did it once before, a few years back, on the PS4. I saw that there had been more content added in the 'final cut' edition and decided to do it all over again. 

Part management, part survival, part stealth, part action, part adventure. part rogue-lite. It's an odd blend that is very much it's own thing. While the game loop itself is great, it's the wonderfully crafted context that really sells it. The visuals, the writing, the characters, the environment and the outstanding music all come together to make a uniquely tangible, depressing and sometimes cosy mood that only this game can offer. Throw in a good amount of replayability and a solid list of achievements to hunt, with no nonsense, and it's practically perfect for what it does. 

[b]Verdict:[/b] I completely recommend it for anyone looking for a challenge or for something a bit different.

101210259.review:
A true masterpiece!!!
This game illustrates the real sad truth of war and the proper approach on how NOT to glorify it. You will play as a citizen caught in war with little to no supplies. You will have to figure out how on earth to survive till the next day till the war ends and work in teams. Throughout the game you are given multiple places that you can only explore when night falls and multiple characters in the beginning of the game, and NO you don't have to go out there and kill everyone rambo style, in order to survive this horrible time. You can even get sick and you will need lots of rest and even meds to recover, you have to play it smart, learn how to trade the right resources and sometimes help people in the same situation you are (or even worse). Most of your decisions will write the ending story (if you can survive that long). You will have to steal sometimes (I wish the impact of still leaving half the food or materials in some houses would also impact the ending of the game) and I'm sorry that the developers  decided the "meat source" you can find in the game was catching rats (or small animals idk).  I am sure making vegetable soups should be no real problem in tough times and you should have more options on what to eat and how to make various warm meals even without meat. I doubt people would choose to eat rat meat (cat/dog whatever) even in those times.  I really hope this survival game has a continuation (more stories/ more options/ more characters... perhaps even character creation) without any real war having to break out as a source of inspiration.

101123413.review:
This War of Mine stands out for addressing the often avoided topic of the plight of civilians during armed conflicts. This is often ignored, not only in video games but media in general, likely because it's harder to glorify pointless suffering for propaganda purposes compared to conventional warfare and the current world superpower considers bombing civilian settlements a valid strategy they still practice to this day. This War of Mine seems to be inspired by the Breakup of Yugoslavia, but many may draw parallels to more recent Syrian Civil War which is still ongoing as of October of 2021.
The game starts somewhat promising, but it only takes a few hours for This War of Mine to become a regular survival game, and I can't help but think this goes against the original intent.
A lot of people mention different set pieces that elicited an emotional reaction from them, but I personally believe the game gets downright cheesy at times. The color palette is mostly comprised of different shades of grey and there's always sad music in the background, it feels forced rather than interactive.
Also, the cyclical nature of the gameplay plus the long duration of the campaign means that by the end of it most players will be thinking about moonshine economics rather than morality. You can only shank an NPC so many times until you become desensitized to it and I highly doubt that's the message they were going for because the sad atmosphere is maintained to the very end. 
However, I find it morbidly cool that your survivors can become so traumatized they basically become catatonic, now that feels like a worthy consequence for some of the awful acts you can commit.
To conclude, This War of Mine has a very interesting and provocative concept, but the execution is more conductive to a fun survival game than an emotional exploration of said concept. Still, it's a fun survival game and I believe that's pretty good too.

101028633.review:
The McCallister family is preparing to spend Christmas in Paris, gathering at Peter and Kate's home in a Chicago suburb on the night before their departure. Peter and Kate's youngest son, Pavle, is the subject of ridicule by his older siblings. Later, Pavle gets into a fight with his older brother Bruno, resulting in him getting sent to the attic of the house, where he wishes that his family would disappear. During the night, heavy winds damage the power lines, which causes a power outage and resets the alarm clocks, causing the family to oversleep. In the confusion and rush to get to the airport, Pavle is accidentally left behind.

Pavle wakes to find the house empty and, thinking that his wish has come true, is overjoyed with his newfound freedom. However, he soon becomes frightened by his next door neighbor, Old Man Marley, a supposed serial killer, as well as the "Wet Bandits", Henrik and Marko, a pair of burglars who have been breaking into other vacant houses in the neighborhood and have targeted the McCallisters' house. Pavle tricks them into thinking that his family is still home, forcing them to put their plans on hold.

Kate realizes mid-flight that Pavle was left behind, and upon arrival in Paris, the family discovers that all flights back to the United States for the next two days are booked. Peter and the rest of the family stay in his brother's apartment in Paris, while Kate manages to get a flight, but only gets as far as Scranton, Pennsylvania. She attempts to book a flight to Chicago, but again, everything is booked. Unable to accept this, Kate is overheard by Gus Polinski, the lead member of a traveling polka band, the Kenosha Kickers, who offers to let her travel with them to Chicago on their way to Milwaukee in a moving van, which she gratefully accepts.

Meanwhile, Henrik and Marko finally realize that Pavle is home alone, and on Christmas Eve, Pavle overhears them discussing plans to break into his house that night. Pavle starts to miss his family and asks the local Santa Claus impersonator if he could bring his family back for Christmas. He goes to church and watches a choir perform, then meets Old Man Marley, who dispels the rumors about him. He points out his granddaughter in the choir, whom he never gets to meet, as he and his son are estranged; Pavle suggests that he should reconcile with his son.

Pavle returns home and rigs the house with booby traps to take on the burglars. Henrik and Marko break in, spring the traps, and suffer various injuries. While the duo pursues Pavle around the house, he calls the police and flees, then lures Henrik and Marko into a neighboring home which they previously broke into. They ambush him and prepare to get their revenge, but Marley intervenes and knocks them unconscious with his snow shovel. The police arrive and arrest Henrik and Marko, having identified all the houses that they broke into due to Marko's destructive characteristic of flooding them.

On Christmas Day, Pavle is disappointed to find that his family is still gone. He then hears Kate enter the house and call for him; they reconcile and are soon joined by Peter, Bruo, Jeff, Megan, and Linnie, who waited in Paris until they could obtain a direct flight to Chicago. Pavle keeps silent about his encounter with Henrik and Marko, although Peter finds Harry's knocked-out gold tooth. Pavle then observes Marley reuniting with his son, daughter-in-law, and granddaughter. Marley notices Pavle, and the pair wave to each other. Just then, Bruo, whose room was damaged during the fiasco, yells at Pavle.

This game does a thoroughly good job of making the player and the characters in the game that you control feel hopelessly caught up in a warzone struggling to survive. The concept itself is pretty novel, and once you learn how to fight back taking the fight to the thugs and looters that have tried to steal your own stuff is satisfying, until your scavenger comes home depressed and hating himself. It reminds you that these are people, and the choices you make end up effecting them at the end of the game. The 2d map style and loot system are all pretty cool, and i've only played one run all the way through so i'm sure there's a lot that I haven't explored yet. Overall, 8/10. Unless the DLC and other starts have some gamechangers with location or playstyle compared to my first run, I can see replayability being low, but what i did play had a gripping and harrowing story that was pretty unique among other games that I have played.

100838238.review:
[h1]History lesson: The Kosovo War[/h1]

[Trigger warning: If you are offended by missing details, maybe to the detriment of your own side, please note that the following paragraph is intended to put the game in the right context. Therefore it is highly simplified. Anything else would go beyond the scope of a game review.
Update: I will now disable the comment function.]

Yugoslavia was a socialist satellite state of the former Soviet Union, patched together after World War 2 from Serbia, Croatia and Bosnia-Herzegovina, among others. After the collapse of the USSR, it fell into a bitter civil war. The Serbian military fought separatist rebels, and because of numerous crimes against the civilian population, the UN finally intervened. The 4-year siege of Sarajevo made particular headlines. This large city was occupied by rebels and besieged by the military. Snipers had almost all streets in view and bombs fell more or less regularly. Rebels, looters and soldiers fought each other, causing great suffering among the civilian people, including the then teenage game developers in whose situation the game throws us. We control a small group of civilians in the bombed city, without weapons, food or even beds.

[h1]Painfully realistic[/h1] 

At first glance, This War Of Mine is just one survival simulation among many. Like in Don't Starve, Rust or The Forest, the goal is to ensure the survival of a small group of characters. In contrast to the rather imaginative scenarios of other survival games, however, this one is about a real, brutal war. The protagonists are not knights in shining armor, but math teachers, TV cooks, warehouse workers, and yet this fight for survival is so much more than a DayZ. The gameplay is often tedious and repetitive. You have to cook food, eat, sleep and rest to be ready for the night. This hopeless cycle perfectly captures the grind of daily survival. Simple, taken-for-granted things like coffee or cigarettes are more valuable than diamonds. Days seem to last endlessly and mistakes are punished without mercy.  Death is permanent and every decision irreversible. If you take the risk of armed combat against other groups, a wounded character may die of his injuries days after. If you exchange valuable medicines for food, they might be missing only a short time later. The nightly raids demand fierce, sometimes immoral decisions and have harsh consequences on the group.

[h1]A simulation?[/h1]

Moreover, there are no fictional end times here that take away the burden of reality, no zombies and no aliens that you can beat up on without a guilty conscience and that make you believe that it won't come to that in reality. No, This War Of Mine has so already happened, it is happening right now and it will happen again. It's Yugoslavia. It's Ukraine, Syria, Gaza, Afghanistan. All over the world there are civilians experiencing exactly what the developers portray so painfully realistically. A war. Right on their doorstep. Right now. That's what makes This War of Mine stand out. It counters the smooth superhero warfare of shooter and strategy games with demoralizing suffering. It's unusual and guaranteed not to entertain. But that's exactly how it's supposed to be.

[h1]Welcome to Hell[/h1]

This War of Mine is a game about feeling powerless and lost. Every seemingly screwed up design element supports this. The incomplete information it reveals about the status of the game's characters creates uncertainty. The combat controls leave no room for finesse, making any exchange of blows with bandits or soldiers unpredictable and, most importantly, undesirable. If a tutorial window explained everything in a friendly way, then the moments when characters react so strongly to events, as in hardly any other game, would not be so shocking.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

It's heavy fare. Being good means having enough food for two days, instead of having to decide who stays hungry. In an interview, designer Pawel Miechhowski answers the question of whether This War of Mine is supposed to be fun: "No, it's supposed to be an experience." It is.
It's an unpleasant experience.
But one that is worth experiencing.

The game itself is very repetitive, basic and almost easy, although I maybe havn't yet progressed far enough on the difficulty curve.

The emotional investment everyone here is lauding wasn't really happening for me. I think the main reason for that is that the morality mechanics aren't really complex enough to reflect (my imagined) game-reality. Stealing from profiteering hagglers or armed killers to ensure the survival of my "very hungry" folks doesn't make me sad. Similar games really had an impact on me, but they're usually about questionable decisions from positions of power, not straight-up survival. Works out for my survivors though, all warm, somewhat fed and sometimes drunk to effectively drown their "sad"ness (which is also not how that probably works).

For me the game wasn't doing its job, both in conveying an anti-war message (which noone really needs to convince me of) and as an actually enjoyable game.

A hauntingly beautiful game. Instead of glorifying war through action and bloodshed, This War of Mine portrays war through the lens of those most impacted by it: regular people. 

With tons of scenarios, over a dozen different survivor groups, 25+ locations with two random states for those locations, two starting houses, many random encounters, and an additional story mode, this game has massive replayability. 

I got the season pass and it was the best value I've gotten on a game as they are constantly adding DLC, keeping the game play fresh and interesting.

There are tons of mods for the game too, but for your first several games, I suggest playing it vanilla for the deepest impact.

Have fun, and try not to get your heart broken.

98582763.review:
Overall I'd probably give this game an 8/10.

The music is great. The game really pushes you into making moral choices that actually can and do have an affect on the characters (both the one doing the act and the ones back at the shelter).

The downside is that you can kill military/thugs/bandits pretty easily and without penalty which ends up making the game feel trivial once you get these areas. It's not hard at all to get an assault rifle, shotgun, military helmet and vest, and bullets and once you have those, a couple rat traps, and a veggie garden you're pretty much set. I've found that usually around day 20 - 25 I'm pretty set. 
I think this comes with how easy the combat can be if you know how to do it well or have the right characters and feel like sneaking. There's definitely a balancing issue there (though maybe the devs felt the game was too hard if combat wasn't the way it is? Idk).

There are player made challenges that you can find online and do yourself using the custom scenario creator in the workshop section (or even create one yourself) which I do appreciate as I feel it adds to the quality of life for the game (which is already pretty good with all the pre-made scenarios).

98380166.review:
TWoM is a very good, atmospheric survival management game because it gives a realistic impression of how to survive a war during an occupation. You have to take care of your people, feed them, make sure they get enough sleep and make sure they don't get depressed. At the same time, it is important to collect enough resources from sometimes dangerous places to upgrade your home and protect it from raids. Once winter sets in, you have to continuously worry about getting enough wood to keep your people warm.
The game could be more difficult though, because once you get to know the locations and how combat works and how to feed your people efficiently, it becomes too easy. Some locations also offer too many resources. 
I'd like an option that would randomize the people, locked doors, and patrol patterns in some locations so you don't know what items to bring and what to find on repeated playthroughs.
The story DLCs are great and also add some variety to the base game.

97462652.review:
[h1]Summary[/h1]
[i]This War of Mine[/i] is a gritty story of survival and sacrifice of civilians in a war zone. If a dark and tragic story isn’t going to speak to you, give it a pass. The survival aspect is easy to learn, but challenging because of the number of resources you have to balance. Mastery of the game is possible, and it loses a bit of magic at that point. You get 4-6 runs before that happens, so it’s worth the price tag in my book. And then you can play the exceptional Stories DLC.
[hr][/hr]
If you’ve come to play [i]This War of Mine[/i], you should be here for the story. This game is somber, gritty, and a bit depressing, but it also reminds you that you are not alone. People thrown together by horrible circumstance work together and help each other…simply because it is the right thing to do. This touch of light was important, and kept the game from being too dark to be playable.

The War has stuffed your city into this handbasket, and you know where you are going. What will you need to do to survive? More importantly, what will you chose to do to survive? Will you steal from the old couple that doesn’t fight back? Will you steal from the bandit? Will you kill him if he catches you? What is the line that separates you from that bandit?

These questions are not just moral hyperbole. If you steal or kill, it can seriously hurt your character’s mental health. Surviving The War is just as much about spirits and morale as finding enough food.

You’re not here to win, you’re here to survive. Some people will struggle with this…I did. During one run, I was asked to make a small sacrifice in order to save the greater good. Even after 6 runs, I still thought “I could do it.” I didn’t make the sacrifice, and I got the worst ending (though the story made sense).

Combat is very dangerous and clunky, and your skill will not matter much. That is the point, though. Violence will be a split-second decision, and you might end up doing something you regret. Sometimes because you lost, sometimes because you won.

Because of these things, this game won’t be for everyone. Some people don’t like real life moral questions and darkness in their games/entertainment. While other people post about killing every bandit and soldier in every run…and I can’t help but feel sad. I feel like they missed the point. Not to mention, if you take morality out of the equation there are better survival/combat games.

In Classic mode, there is very little overarching plot. The story is driven by your characters, choices, and random events. Some events are small (help board your neighbor’s windows), while others change how you approach the game (starting during the dead of winter). Despite being driven by random events, the pieces come together very well, and I survived about 4 runs before I needed a more structured story.

[i]This War of Mine: Stories[/i] is what you are really here for. The stories are exceptional, and add a lot of life to the game. Stories adds some new twists and challenges, so make sure you can survive The War in Classic, before you try Stories.

[i]This War of Mine[/i] is also a surprisingly good survival game that requires to you balance a lot of factors. How do you manage your daytime get everyone food and rest, while maintaining and upgrading the house? Who goes scavenging and who gets some much-needed sleep…do you post a guard against raiders? Where do you scavenge? Sites with guards have better stuff, but require a lot of time sneaking, limiting what you can do…[i]if[/i] you don’t get caught. Do you use precious backpack slots to bring a weapon or lockpicks? Do you bring back food? Meds for your sick child? Electronics for your workbench? Jewelry (don’t knock the jewelry…you can trade a few useless baubles for an entire backpack full of lumber)? Each individual piece of the survival game is simple, but the number of things you constantly balance adds just the right amount of complexity.

I think the best praise I can give the survival game is that I enjoyed the process. When I played a Story and got an ending I didn’t like, I didn’t hesitate to fire up that story again because I enjoyed the process of playing the game.

The biggest weakness for me is that you can solve the game. Once you understand how all the pieces move, you can make “correct” choices that allow you to easily survive, get all your upgrades, and not have to make any tough choices. After that, the magic of the game was gone. The good news is that took about 6 runs, so I felt like I got a good value out of the game.

No matter how many times I keep coming back to this game, wanting to install it and make it happen, I just can't get into it. The story is cliche, progression feels bland, and the only challenge comes from managing annoyances effectively. If I didn't know any better, I would say that half way through development, they recognized that progression was too boring, and needed to throw in all those random annoyances in order to make it feel like there is some element of skill involved.

There is only 1 real way to play the game, 1 strategy, and only very subtle nuances in how you execute that strategy. It has everything that it needs to make for an excellent game (sound, art, controls, atmosphere is excellent), but fails on a foundational level. Choices do feel like they have consequences, which is important, but at absolutely no point do I ever feel like I OWN those consequences. I didn't make a mistake.. The game just randomly decided that I made a mistake, and that isn't something I can derive entertainment from.

Will YOU enjoy this game? Maybe.. If you find war-story driven games compelling, you'll probably enjoy a single play through then put it away forever. But like I said at the start, the story is pretty cliche. It tries to tug on your emotions the same way a toddler might tug on a pickup truck-- ineffectively.

96443116.review:
An excellent, difficult game that isn't afraid to be difficult. Like the studio's other release that I've played, Frostpunk, This War of Mine creates mood and atmosphere like few other titles; in fact, I hope the developer's listen to peppy tunes when they are working, because the oppressive atmosphere is tough to shake (everything from the art direction to the score and tough choices lead us to this feeling).

The game doesn't teach you how to play it - learning how to survive is your job.  There is only one thing I feel like the game should tell you, and I'm going to do it at the bottom of the review.  As you learn to survive, you must push towards self-sufficiency and make tough choices.  Invest in that self-sufficiency too soon, and you'll have great equipment but nothing to run it.  Avoid that investment, and you won't be able to scavenge what you need later when things take a grim turn.

There are only two things about the game that I would improve:
1.) The soundtrack is too limited and needs expansion.  The tunes on the radio especially need more variety.  
2.) Save slots - I get it, you want to make it challenging and more realistic, but consider that we might want to have more than one adventure going with a different group of survivors. 

Overall, it's a fantastic and challenging game.  Play when you're in a good mood.

The spoiler I mentioned: Death is forever.  If you can't handle a fight, don't push your luck.

I have been playing this game since 2014 every now and then, but I only decided now to write a small review about it.

To skip the obvious part, this game is about the reality of war, the one what the average people would and have to experience as civilians.

The game can be ‘pleasantly’ depressing, if you have sympathy and value human life.
You can complete the game without killing anyone nor stealing anything, but you WILL see suffering which you can have an impact on.

Gameplay wise it is very enjoyable, it will take a bit of time and practice to master the mechanics, but once you do, you can build up a pretty profitable alcohol, bandage, tobacco business, so your survivors can live a pretty decent life.
What I also like about the game that there is no save scumming, so it gives you a challenge deciding what to do, what to risk. (Of course you can alt+tab the game, to reset the day, but what’s the fun about that?)

Overall, It is a fantastic game which captures the true nature of war (based on siege of Sarajevo) and by buying it, a portion of the money will go directly to children/people in need so I recommend this game to anyone who like this genre and wants to do a good deed.
