96242794.review:
TL;DR: Absolutely worth it for it's unique, realistic narrative. Also a very solid survival game, unlike some of the studio's other products.

---------

If you somehow missed this game back in 2014, get it. This War of Mine is a survival game without the zombies, the dinosaurs, the fantasy. This is a game grounded in reality, inspired by the Siege of Sarajevo.

Yes, it's grueling and depressive. For civilians, war is devoid of glory and nobility. But you don't have to do cruel and inhumane things to survive as a civilian. Not with mastery of the game's mechanics. Perhaps getting too good at the game takes away from the key messages of helplessness and the need to make evil choices in order to survive. I don't care. My survivors would rather eat rats everyday than rob the elderly couple living nearby. We're resolved to come out of the war with our conscience intact. And we came out of the war alive.

I couldn't ask for more. This game is very much deserving of all the awards it earned (over 100).

95633917.review:
OK, here it is (2021, July, 12th):

I have now played 50+ hours of “This War of Mine”.

This game is great. I love it!

I completed the first scenario (45 days – in-game) in about 30 hr (real-time/my time/game play), after 6-7 restarts (trials and errors – to learn the rules – To me, it was a normal learning curve).

I played a 2nd snenario in about 15 hrs ( my time) ( 45 hrs in-game). 

Here, you control civilians (3 at first), you improve their shelter, scavenge food, mats, medicines, weapons, etc. and you try to carry them through 45-days of war. 

I actually created bonds with the characters (3 at first) I controlled. Quickly, I cared for them and I wanted them to survive (and you will too), and when they actually do (after 45 days - if played correctly; in  the 1st scenario) you feel like you really achieved something. You feel good.To me, this game is addictive, immersive. This game is that great! 

This game shows you a different side of war: the civilian side! It certainly succeeds 100%. You have to make decisions, some are difficult: will you share some of you valuable ressources with a neighbor? Will you help your neighbor?

The learning curve is just fine: 6-7 restarts, 6-7 days, after 1-2 hr of actual gameplay each: If I, a 65 yo white man can do it, certainly, you can! 

In summary: Great game; great value; great “life lesson”. Share when you can / help the needy, do not be selfish, Wow! Seems like moral values from another era are very much alive, at least in this game! Grats to the developers! 

Jorunar’ Seal of Approval! 5/5!

(My 1st language is French; English is a distant 3rd language. Plz, forgive my errors/mistakes. 
See you in "This War of Mine"!

94846905.review: The game is fun and engaging. There's plenty to do, and I never felt bored. The scavenger missions are full of options. You can either sneak around or go in guns blazing. The story is intricate and well thought out, and the visuals are amazing. The setting feels pretty real, with real stakes. When people die, they die for good. And it's heartbreaking to watch someone slowly starve, fall into depression, or get sick. My only critique is that the atmosphere is really bleak all the time. I always felt kind of down and sad after a game cause there were never any light moments to relieve the tension, but I guess that's intentional to make it feel like a real war zone. I will also say, the community mods make the game more fun and bearable, so be sure to look at them. One mod lets you hold more stuff when you go out to scavenge, which makes those missions less frustrating and ultimately let's you do more in the game, so you don't have to visit the same location 100 times just to collect enough wood to make a bed. In summary, good value for the price.

94825327.review:
"In modern war... you will die like a dog for no good reason."

[i]This War of Mine[/i] is a war survival video game developed and published by 11 bit studios.

[b]Story[/b]
Set in fictional city called Porogen in Graznavia, you control a group of civilians who try to survive this seemingly neverending nightmare that is war.

Game is inspired by poor living conditions and wartime atrocities that Bosnian civilians endured during the 1992–96 Siege of Sarajevo, the longest city siege since World War II.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
This War of Mine features survival-themed gameplay with strategy elements in 2.5 D perspective.
Gather resources and manage them, craft items and explore ruined city in order to live another day, and maybe survive long enough to make it to the end of the war.

Gameplay can be seperated into two major parts, daytime and nighttime.

During daytime due to enemy snipers you and your group stays in shelter, damaged house that now serves as home. Here you can manage all resources you have collected, and your entire group, which can be up to 4 characters.
Rest, heal wounds and sickness, eat and craft items necessary for survival. When you start you have only a basic workbench, which can be upgraded, or used to build different structures that will help you craft all kinds of items.
Here you can also encounter random events, as once in a while to your door someone will knock. It might be a local trader, or someone looking for help. You have a limited time here so you can't wait and waste it.

As night falls, you are able to explore the city for supplies. Here you pick a location and a person that will explore it, and decide what to do with the rest of group. You can set up a watch to prevent (or attempt to prevent) thieves from stealing or from bandit group to raid your shelter for resources, or let them rest so they can be ready for the upcoming day.
Exploration is rather easy to figure out, you make your way through different parts of Porogen to obtain electronics, food, and more. With limited backpack, you have to think what items you need and which you can leave for another time. Some of the items you created in shelter will help to make your way through the collapsed buildings and closed doors.
Be sure to look at the time, as staying until sunrise means tougher way back home. When it comes to controls, you only use your mouse to click and move characters, and all elements such as doors or lootable places are pointed out, making it easy to interract with them.

Game puts a huge emphasis on humans. Your characters need food, a safe place to rest and relax. If they will get sick or wounded, you have to patch them up. Some of them also have their addictions which you should try and satisfy.
They can have different moods depending on actions you make, each improving or decreasing it, with worst leading even to suicide.
Characters also have a little background and backstory which unlocks as you progress through the scenario.
They all have different abilities that will help you make through the war. Some are skilled builders and require less resources to make items, some are good at trading, letting you have more for less, while some with bigger backpack space are a perfect choice for night go-outs. Figuring out and using different characters for different actions is important and puts an even bigger emphasis on survival, as everyone in your group is important.
Each scenario has a mixture of different characters so you have to constantly change your approach to make the best out of them.
Humans live outside of your shelter too. Bandits roam the areas and raid them for resources, and they will fight you if they spot you. You have to resolve to stealth or to fighting back. Civilians will attack if you trespass or steal their items.
Locations have a notification about danger or caution, so you know in which areas things might take a wrong turn.

[b]Playtime, replayability and other modes[/b]
One day and night cycle takes 10 minutes on average to make your way through. Due to different amount of days in offical scenarios, and huge replayability it's impossible to point out how much time game will absorb. 
Main point of the game is replayability. To use different characters in different scenarios, where hostilty and lenght, even a starting location is different. To figure out mechanics of the game and how to optimize resource management for another run to be even better. TWoM is defintely a game that you have to play multiple times and spend a while to squeeze out the best out of it.
Besides offical scenarios, there is Workshop! Here you can make your own scenario, where you choose characters, locations, level of hostility and amount of days to the end. You can also create your own characters and share them with community!

[b]Pros and cons[/b]
While gameplay doesn't bring anything new to the survival nor management genre, it is quite enjoyable to play. Enjoyable in a slighty despair way. It's easy to get into the game and figure out what you have to do, but it takes some time to learn the approach, check out structures and locations in order to make another run better than previous one. Easy to learn controls and friendly UI help in making game accessible to majority.
Previously mentioned human factor is also a fantastic element of the game. From narrative perspective, each character with story and background which unlocks as you progress adds the brutality of war layer, as everyone tries to survive in order to find loved ones and return to normal life. They have different aspects of morality and portray war in multiple ways.
If you look at gameplay side, different skills, statistics of characters, and focus on their survival adds to the, well, survival-management part.
Pencil drawn artstyle allows the game to look unique, and goes well with fitting soundtrack accompanying you throughout it.
Pretty much all bugs or performance issues have been fixed in updates (although I experienced some translation issues in DLC part of the game).

I can't think of anything that would be a major negative point in the game.
Some people might not be a fan of hidden statistics, I'm talking about how different characters have different combat abilities, speed and how well they manage in stealth.

[b]Final words and conclusion[/b]
If you want even more misery, you can buy Little Ones DLC, which adds children characters you have to take care off, or Stories, combination of This War of Mine gameplay with more story-driven experience. 

A highly recommend title that mixtures survival-management gameplay and fantastic artstyle with horrific, yet often not portrayed side of war.

Check out [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/31947302/] my curator page for more reviews! [/url]

94634119.review: This was the first game that I ever bought. My friend recommended it to me at the start of the Pandemic and it felt so real. This is a rare game that doesn't glorify war. There are no winners here, only survivors struggling to get through the night. 94625559.review:
You can really tell when a game was made by people passionate about the art and message they want to get across, and this is one of those games. It's not about being a soldier or a hero or even a villain, it's about ordinary citizens caught up in the crossfires of a war they have no wish to participate in. You play to get them through this nightmare they've been thrown into and boy does this game make you feel that. The main mechanic is survival and resource-management. You go out every night to scavenge supplies and bring them back to a shelter which you can build and improve to make your group's lives more sustainable and comfortable. If you run into other survivors or soldiers, there is the possibility of combat, trade, or alliance. You will encounter situations where you have to make difficult choices and face their consequences. The game does well at drawing out that feeling of desperation from the player, mirroring those of the survivors you're trying to keep alive, and huge relief/satisfaction when you succeed. You can choose to get through without hurting anyone or stealing, or, you can choose to do those things. Characters have different levels of morality and some will become depressed (which comes with actual mechanical consequences) if you do bad things, or gain a boost of hope and morale if you do good. There is also a high replay value with the variation in character group combinations (each one having different strengths and weaknesses) as well as scavenging locations that you can't see all of in just one run. The story pulls no punches as far as tragedy yet manages not to be too heavy handed while delivering it. The game does not need to convince you when events are heartbreaking; you will feel that without the game's help. It's meant to highlight the horrors or war, not to glorify it, not even to choose a side. It's very well done in both writing and art style. Sound design is incredible, sound effects are satisfying and music is beautiful. And. It's just really fun to play. 
There's so much more to it than I've written here, so it's definitely worth playing for yourself.

94619833.review: Its nice to see a war game that does not glorify war.  I loved the experience of bonding with my characters, as i struggled to provide them with enough medicine, food, and recreation while they live in a war zone.  Struggling for supplies at night becomes a a process you are invested in, and finding a gem, or a useful tool provides some nice gaming vibes.  When a character gets injured and you get medicine just in time to rescue them from the brink of death, you really feel like you accomplished something.  If you like strategy or survival games, or you simply want a different take on armed conflict from a video game i definitely suggest checking it out.

94611808.review:
This War of Mine is a good survival game with addictive gameplay. You manage a group of civilians trying to survive. The gameplay cycle has a day phase where you spend time in your base doing things like cooking, crafting and upgrading. The night phase involves choosing a survivor to go out and scavenge, while others stay home to sleep or guard your base against attacks. The game is littered with moral dilemmas, such as stealing from other innocent people trying to survive or choosing to help (or not help) neighbours who need things like food or medicine.

This game isn't perfect and it has a few janky spots like clunky combat and the lack of a tutorial explaining basic game mechanics. I also don't think that the loot amount and what is needed is well balanced, but that is more of a personal preference as I hate survival games that start off as a tedious grind (this is easily fixed with a mod which increases the loot slightly).

Overall, this is a really good game with interesting choices. The devs have done a pretty good job of keeping it fresh by randomising things like your base location or which survivors you can start with (and which have their own likes / dislikes and skills). The biggest success is that you really feel the desperation of the setting and you feel pushed to make difficult choices. One moment that still haunts me is when I chose to steal from an old couple as my survivors were in desperate need of food. The old man followed me around the house begging me to stop stealing and to at least leave them something :( I abandoned that game shortly afterwards as I couldn't bear to keep playing. I still feel like a piece of crap and hear his pleading in my sleep.

THE DLC:
Unfortunately, my first experience of the DLC wasn't great. I started with Father's Promise. I'm not really a fan of linear gameplay in survival games, and the stories seem very directed and on rails. I also found the main character, Adam, really annoying - his forced depressed state makes him constantly whine and stop doing whatever task you set him to. I couldn't bear his nonsense any more after 8 days and abandoned the DLC. After reading the story conclusion online, I am glad I didn't waste any more time on that cliched nonsense. Perhaps the other stories in the DLC will be better. That being said, my enjoyment of the base game was not diminished and I look forward to more runs.

94589352.review: Pretty good simulation to get yourself ready for what is coming.

94585958.review: completely effective in it´s goal of setting a dire tone of civilians suffering through a war in their city, while also managing to be an enticing gameplay system. Not easy to pull off!

94577707.review:
This is a really fun game and is one of the few that I have played on both Mobile and PC. Its a fantastic strategy game where you manage a group of survivors stuck in a warzone and unlike with most modern survival games, its in unban setting, you actually start to give a damm about the characters, and the ways you can win are numerous and the only rule is really to survive until the ceasefire.

I'm no expert in this game, but I really do enjoy playing it despite sometimes doing something stupid like getting greedy for food and medicine when I already have like 16 meat and 10 bandages (veterans of the game look upon this point and laugh you are allowed to, just let me get my dunce cap first).

I really have only 2 complaints and thats that it could benefit from a tutorial mode like maybe the first of the stories is a tutorial or the first scenerio is a tutorial, heck it doesnt have to be long it could just be for a few weeks of in game time, and I believe you could introduce all the things nesscery to guide new players to success instead of letting them stumble around in the dark or be forced to go to the wikia for help.

The second complaint is the lack of save features and how there is only autosave. If your looking for more realism feel free to dismiss this, but if your like me and wish the game had a function that would enable a rockstar gta type of save feature with the trade off that you cant earn achievements, that could work for those of us who want to play around and see what we can get away with. Just a suggestion moving on

Conclusion: this is a short review but I dont have much to say really, its a great survival game and its unique with its characters, setting, and scenerio. I highly reccommend it, though it could use a manual save feature and a tutorial for newbies trying to survive in the war torn city of Porgoran ( I hope I spelled that right)

9/10
point deducted for lack of manual save and tutorial

94418286.review:
As you know, this is a game about being a civillian during war. You have to gather resources, defend your base, build new crafting stations and maybe even kill to survive. The soundtrack and atmosphere are absolutely stunning, the graphics, while imperfect, have a nice art style and the DLCs are all worth the price. 
    My main issue is the difficulty. While the game is hard during your first playthrough, the difficulty is mostly artificial and with enough experience you can easily survive anything, especially with the right survivors, after which the gameplay becomes tedious, since you can stay at your home, flood the local market with expensive stuff and buy everything you need from traders, who are almost everywhere. This results in you having to do challenge runs to make the game replayable.
    Another issue is that your survivors don't feel human after some time. Sure, they have backtsories, might get depressed and kill themselves if they experience too much, but during night, they will do anything you order them. Rob the local hospital? Yeah, sure. Kill a soldier? Ok, done. Kill an innocent civillian? Nvm, he's already dead. They don't react at all during night and after killing soldiers or thugs their only concern during day is that it was dangerous. Some are more empathetic than others, but is also reduced to a system that can be optimized. The only reason you differentiate them at all are their abilities, some of which are unreasonably strong and some severely underpowered. This removes a lot of immersion, further broken by some illogical things, like for example taking anything, even a single grain of coffee from the old couple's house will [spoiler]have them dead the next time you visit the location[/spoiler].
    Overall, a very solid and emotional game, but only for the first playthrough. After that it doesn't have much to offer, aside from the DLCs.

94417092.review: I care about the characters in "This War of Mine." The ugly heartache, loneliness and pain of war are inescapable. Working with with others, even when there is no apparent gain, is encouraged. This is a smart game. It's smart because it provokes contemplation of war. It's not just another Kill On Site (KOS) game. The game is based on what comes before, after and during the mindless KOS. You start winning when you find solutions that work for your community. I would recommend it for older children and up.

94217920.review:
This War Of Mine is an emotional, intense, and challengeing experience as you observe and control the actions of various surviving civilians in the center of a war torn city.
The game itself is based on a pretty simple concept(survive and thrive) split into two rotating phases - day and night. During the day you make food, build new things, have your survivors interact with each other, and deal with ailments or wounds. Nighttime is where you decide wether you want to send out one of your survivors to scavenge, guard the shelter, or sleep. Typically scavenging is the most fruitful option, as it's your main source of many of the important resources needed to create your nescessities. It's also the most gameplay-rich part of the game as you have both a time-limit and an inventory limit to consider. You will sometimes, however, have to adapt to the situation you're in and either stay put, or take a risk and scavenge in a potentially dangerous location.
For me this is the greatest strength of the game. It's quite difficult, and it's VERY punishing if you make a mistake, while also being greatly rewarding if you do something right.
The graphic is a perfect fit to the game's spirit; the environments are diverse and not repetitive and while the music themes can be a bit repetitive they do create a very good atmosphere.
In all, if you like survival games for the sense of vulnerability and intensity they provide, if you appreciate rogue-like games, you will definitively love This War Of Mine.

94180885.review:
Un juego Hermoso! casi perfecto.

No tiene tutoriales, lo que extrañamente lo hace mejor, pues debes aprender todo al sopapo, lo que en cierto modo te deja en la misma situación de tus personajes, que son meros civiles intentando sobrevivir a en una ciudad sitiada por una guerra civil. Cada personaje tiene una historia particular que se desarrolla al largo de la partida y que puede variar según su final, hay muchos que te van a desgarrar el corazón, es un juego que apela mucho a lo emocional, y con derecho, pues toca temas reales. Así que en lo que se trata de temática e historia es perfecto.

Un tema importante es que este juego tiene un dlc exclusivo para realizar donaciones a la Ong War Child que ayuda a niños que están viviendo la situación que estas experimentando en el juego, es un detalle muy considerado de los desarrolladores así como algo que te hace tomar mucha conciencia sobre el juego, no un simples pasatiempos, es la cruda realidad para mucha gente. 

Con respecto al gameplay, es muy bueno aun que tiene un punto en contra. El juego exige una administración de recursos muy cuidadosa, incluida el tiempo, tomar decisiones buenas y malas para sobrevivir, aprender de tus errores y tomar riesgos que pueden ser fatales. Todo esto mencionado te da buenas horas de entretenimiento y aprendizaje, con cada partida nueva intentas ser un mejor sobreviviente. El punto en contra, es que el juego da la sensación, o al menos a mi, que era un juego que ofrecería muchas horas de juego, pero cuando aprendes a dominar su mecánica empieza a volverse poco atractivo, es como si le faltara algo mas en la gameplay y me paso lo mismo con otro juego de la misma desarrolladora, el juego aparenta que va para muchas horas y luego de dominar su dificulta se estanca ya no me interesa mas y tampoco algún día en el futuro volver a jugarlo, ese segundo detalle me intriga mas. Y estoy seguro que la intencion era que diera mas horas de juego por que tienes como 10 o 12 tipos de inicio diferente, con varios tipos distintos de sobreviviente. pero ya a la 5nta o 6ta partida ya no entretiene mas y hay personajes que sin duda deben de tener historias geniales que me las voy a pasar por que no pegan ganas. 

A pesar de ese ultimo detalle que siempre me intriga, que es lo que le falta a la gameplay, es un juego excelente, una experiencia única, una compra segura y la oportunidad de que dejes de ser un inútil y ayudes al planeta tierra, aun que sea sentado en tu pc comprando su dlc/donación y así podrás decirle a tus viejos que no estas simplemente jugando, estas viciando para hacer de este mundo un lujar mejor jajaja.

94135925.review:
It's a game that is both fun and meaningful, more of an exercise in morality than strictly survival. My only real complaint is that you eventually just get set for the rest of the game and no longer really struggle after a few weeks. A single run requires you to survive about 45 days, and I would no longer need to scavenge at all by around day 30, and that was even without doing any particularly immoral actions, as I mostly just attacked bandits or soldiers and didn't steal from other civilians, and was able to stay afloat entirely by my own production and occasional trade.
It's a very nice game, and you could easily maximize the efficiency of your shelter if you just ignored the moral dilemmas and focused only on your own survival, but the point of the game is clearly much more about exploring humanity in a hopeless setting. The DLC stories are much more linear and focused further on those themes of humanity, and are a nice addition overall. The game overall is pretty good, it just wears out over time, I think the first few weeks are the best part and the enjoyment just starts to decline after that.

93835245.review:
First, the good.  If you're looking for a game with a gritty atmosphere that has crafting and survival elements, this is for you.  It's got a good story, good lore, real choices with real consequences, real survival and crafting strategy.  All good things.  

Now, why did I give it a thumbs down?  

Because I have a scoped rifle.  I love scoped rifles in other games, they're awesome.  As soon as I found out one was actually available in this game I spent hours trying to successfully get it.  In the hands of the NPCs, they play about as you'd expect - scoped rifle in a fire field pretty much means you're dead unless you've got really great cover options, speed, and a bit of luck.  

But when the PC has the scoped rifle, well then the rules change and you're some dumb kid fighting a Terminator... using a semi-automatic weapon, with no way to use the scope that makes the rifle logically deadly in other people's hands.  Take cover?  Doesn't really matter, the enemy has full auto fire or shotguns.  Surprise attack for bonus damage (say, like a SNIPER would)?  Nope.  You get to make one shot, then you die.

So yeah.  This game gets a thumbs down from me because the weapon that is the hardest to get is a deathtrap for you... but it's the hammer of god in the hands of the enemies.

93826946.review: It's a great game and a great concept, but even in the 'Final Cut' stage of development, it suffers from infuriating random bugs where friendly people suddenly attack my pacifist, help-the-kids scavenger and beat him to death. It's happened in the Church (without stealing or even interacting with anyone, they just bust down the door and attack - what did I do?), it's happened in the Central Square, and it makes no sense at all when it happens. The same scavenger who says, Oh, hi, don't worry about me, later says I'm not finished with you punk and pulls my guy off a ladder and beats him to death next to the priest. SInce it's a hardcore game, that's the end. Would be fine if it made any sense, but it doesn't, and is a gut punch after investing the time to build up a hideout. The other bugs are forgivable in a unique game with a unique message, but this is precisely the wrong thing to allow to happen to the player.

93822632.review: This is a fun game that makes you really think about your choices. There's plenty of moral choices you can make in multiple places, whether it's saving a girl from a soldier trying to take advantage of her, or murdering and robbing an elderly couple in their home, both of which being things I've done in different playthroughs. I wish I didn't have to do the latter, but the game does so much it sometimes makes you have no choice, forcing you to do terrible things for resources you're desperate form. I just love this game and the base management it has, though that may be helped by my love for RTS games.

93608711.review: From a purely mechanical perspective being a (based) psychopath is the optimal playstyle and largely trivializes the game. The devs try to counterbalance this by 1) having the character you control constantly (they never shut up) whine about what you did and 2) Giving you a bad ending if you're a (based) psycho. I found these measures to be ineffective since I never felt immersed in the world. You don't learn character's backstories organically (i.e. they don't talk like normal ppl you just click on a card and read a summary) nor do they have any endearing quirks. You act as a tardwrangler controlling a bunch of annoying tomodachi pets constantly whining about how war is bad and stuff man. Nobody is likeable so I always revert to being a (based) psycho. A smart game would maybe have had its characters become inured to this and have their dialogue change since they're becoming a sith lord. This game does no such thing. If you want anti-war themes Metal (autism) Gear has more profundity and still manages to be fun. If you want a survival management go play anyone of the million such games. This War of Mine falls flat in terms of being both anti-war and a fun game.

93604213.review:
Beautiful and fitting art style. Also contains some minor character story elements to give NPCs more life so you'll feel bad for robbing and killing them. 

War of Mine has become a classic of its kind, a game one should be aware of when talking about a resource management de facto point-and-click survival game. Also a factor leading to my negative review was having the expectation that this game truly is something special. People tend to like this game because of its atmosphere, the dilemmas it puts you in, questioning your moral compass, and this is enough for many people. However, I feel like in terms of atmosphere, or rather immersion (since they're [b]really[/b] trying to enforce this serious, yet realistic, dark vibe), they have kinda failed when one takes time to look through the disguise and at the gameplay at hand. Following things are more or less present in all games of this kind in a way or another, so you feel at home if you like them:

> You have to filter rain water with stuff you found in a pile of debris because rain is apparently dirty, giving you rectal-turbo-tuberculosis (I wish, there'd at least be an option to use it with a downside) - even going so far that you have to waste resources on filtering it when watering plants... yes, plants...
> You live in a broken house with redundant wooden furniture but still have to spend a night gathering firewood in different buildings because you don't have -...a hatchet? Remember, people die because of this. It's not the game setting's circumstances that defeated you, it's the game. Doesn't matter if there's a big wooden fence around your house.
> Bandits steal your stuff but you don't get their loot when defeating them - on maps, they also have infinite ammo until you loot them but else would've surprised me.
> Lockpicks break after one use, minor issue because it's a classic.
> Game doesn't give you instructions, two weeks had passed before I figured out that sprinting was a thing...
> Only one person can scavenge at night, rest is just getting stabbed and digesting or something, I don't know.
> Doesn't matter how long you're scavenging, always the same malus on Tired stat.
Note that much of this is only an issue because they're trying to set the atmopheric and immersive bar high. You just keep getting reminded that's it's a stat juggling game with the wrong meat on the bone. It's thus not much different than other games of its kind.

Now, I do not like the average resource management survival game because I like having some "reason to care" around me that's not simply balancing stat meters because it's what the game tells me to do. Resource usage just doesn't seem to rhyme with reason. Without me being able to dive into the world that is This War of Mine, the atmosphere as the advertised selling point of this game, the reason to play, is diminishing.

It is not unlikely that you will like or even love the game. Also not unlikely that you drop it after playing it once or twice.
I'm not judging you if you still like the game, for me it's just "one of these". It is not worse than other games of its kind, it's just that I didn't get what the trailer, the game told me I'd experience.

93431617.review:
This War of Mine captures the balance between the simplicity and complexity of survival more than most computer games can.  Although in most campaigns there is very little story utilized in the overall flow, small moments of humanity shine through.  Whether savagery or kindness drive your in-game intensions, this game demands sacrifices that the player must reconcile with.  After playing through the base game and learning the locations and timing to best up my survival rate, I still felt engaged with the overall atmosphere and determination of many of the characters.  I wanted to beat the odds and make survival not only viable, but also containing some margin of comfort for everyone to come out the other side a little less damaged than they might have been.

This game works well both as a medium strategy game and an engrossing survival sim.  I highly recommend it to those who like those games and who enjoy hard-hitting minimalist storytelling that takes into account the impact of your choices.  This is a game that feels very different to play than it does to watch.

Edit: Having sunk time into it, I did become compelled to complete it and have finally done so... but my thoughts haven't changed too much from my initial review. 

I am going to give it a modest thumbs up for its simplicity when it comes to crafting/survival. There are a lot of freedom in terms of routes you can take, but they all revolve around the idea of stay sufficient until the war passes. 

- Original review with a few corrections -

Interesting game... but probably not for everyone.

This game is comparable to something like Oregon Trail. You have a group of people who must survive over a period of time until a goal is met. Instead of moving in a wagon, you hang out in a dilapidated house. Instead of Oregon, you are in the middle of a war torn city. However both games have you forced to collect the essentials... food, medicine and weapons. 

When it comes to the downsides of this particular game, you can feel pushed pushed into a scenario without a clear idea of how to progress until it is too late. I have had to restart the game a few times because somebody will die and there will be some game play aspect you won't learn until you unknowingly make a mistake. 

The game can also feel kind of boring and repetitive towards the end. During the simulation/build mode it is recommended to quickly do whatever task is needed whether it be cook food or build, then send them straight to bed so they can be awake in order to guard at night. 

I like the look and atmosphere of the game, but at the moment it is a little too frustrating for my taste. Maybe I will go back to it with a better review, but for those of you wondering what to expect...

92529876.review:
This game does a very good job of setting the mood and bringing you into the war-torn city aesthetic. Things are bleak, miserable, and everyday is a struggle. Getting ahead means stealing or hurting someone else, but when it comes down to it, what other options do you have? You are fighting for your survival but also struggling with the morality of what you're forced to do. You manage a group of characters and they all have their own strength, vices, and personalities. 

As far as gameplay, it's not very engaging and generally a slog. The base management mechanic is needlessly open-ended and could easily be simplified with a cleaner interface (although this would maybe remove some of the impact of the bleakness of the game). The exploration is interesting but very janky/unclear in terms of visibility and interaction, which makes this already unforgiving game even more unforgiving. A full play-through takes way too long - my first and only complete run probably took 3-4 hours and I spent the last 10 or so days sleeping through the day and guarding at night since I had amassed plenty of supplies and just needed to wait until the war ended, and there was no benefit to leaving.

I'd recommend playing this game for 1-2 hours just to experience the aesthetic and feel the bleakness of the world that's been built, but in terms of gameplay, it's hardly notable and not worth the time. I've decided to change my review from negative to positive since I think it's a unique and worthwhile experience; I was just a bit disappointed at the weak gameplay.

92393060.review:
[h1]Argumento[/h1]

[h1]Sobrevivir en tiempos de guerra[/h1]

Es el contexto principal desde el cual se desarrollan las historias de los personajes que se pueden seleccionar en el juego. Cada uno de ellos tiene una peculiaridad que los diferencia entre sí, teniendo el mismo objetivo en común, sobrevivir. Esto, pasando por situaciones muy complejas, durante los días en los que el conflicto transcurre.  

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

El juego está centrado en la supervivencia en términos generales. Debes conseguir alimento, medicinas y agua fundamentalmente. El refugio en el cual se desarrollan las partidas, tiene algunos elementos al inicio de las mismas, los cuales ayudaran a implementar mejoras que permiten sobrevivir los primeros días y estar en buenas condiciones en los días posteriores, como, por ejemplo, camas para que los personajes puedan dormir bien y puedan descansar cuando están enfermos, estufa, para poder cocinar los alimentos, filtros de agua, entre otros.
 
El refugio también tiene otras mejoras, se puede construir un taller de herramientas para fabricar palas, palancas y ganzúas para forzar cerraduras, hojas de cierra para cortar rejas, entre otras. Estas herramientas se utilizan durante los saqueos a otros sitios, a los cuales deberás ir en las noches en busca de recursos. En algunos sitios se puede comerciar, otros están deshabitados y en algunos se corre el riesgo de que puedan asesinar a tu personaje. La moral de los personajes puede verse afectada dependiendo de sus actos. Si tuviste que robar, o matar durante alguna búsqueda, afectara el comportamiento y actitud, al punto en que un personaje puede quedar completamente inutilizable. El refugio también puede ser saqueado durante las noches, por lo que tendrás que definir bien, quien duerme y quién vigila en cada noche. 

La partida concluye, una vez se anuncia el cese al fuego después de haber transcurrido varios días de conflicto. 

[h1]Apartado técnico[/h1] 

El juego es en un solo plano, con algunos aspectos 2.5D, lo cual da una sensación de profundidad en algunos elementos. Puedes ver el interior del refugio y todos los niveles, muy similar en este aspecto al video juego “vecino infernal”. Durante los saqueos, solo puedes ver lo que está en frente, en cada habitación y en cada nivel si las puertas están abiertas. La ambientación está muy bien, es muy sutil, pero está bien lograda.

[h1]Conclusión[/h1]

El juego tiene muchos aspectos positivos, en la relación calidad, precio, vale la pena. Si te gustan los juegos de supervivencia en los cuales, te la pases muy bien, pasándola mal, deberías darle una oportunidad a este título. Como aspecto negativo, me queda la sensación de que algunas de las cosas que se pueden construir en el refugio, no son de mucha utilidad. Algunos elementos que se pueden fabricar a partir de ciertos talleres, toman mucho tiempo y no valen la espera realmente. Por lo demás, me parece un muy buen juego. Me siento afortunado de haberlo recibido de manera gratuita y de paso, agradezco de nuevo a la persona quien me lo regalo ya hace un tiempo, muchas gracias :)

92200240.review:
Overall great survival, 10/10 without a doubt. The story is absolutely dashing, same goes for the overall tone.

The setting is realistic, grim dark and sends shivers down even the most resilent of spines. Man made horrors are shown in the most brutal, straightforward way possible, impacting the player heavily, sudenly and without the ability to go back.

Your decisions truly seem to matter and have great weight, sometimes even showing that having your best interests at heart is not enough to save those you love. It´s a story of pain, loss, but also rebuilding, hope and morality.

The morality is very impactful, but I must say I found some characters extremely annoying - they were unfit for survival on their own - yet I cared. Why? Because I growed to take them as a part of the family, which had to be cared about and their fragility became a serious issue which had to be handled. 

In the end, even the more infuriating mechanics clicked together into a perfectly balanced story and gameplay, which kept me hooked in for many hours. Definitely a game to play, the only thing you need is a strong stomach and the strenght to do the right thing - or not, it´s up to you.

91742035.review:
This War of Mine is one of those unforgettable indie games that people who are into the survival genre, doesn’t matter whether it is zombies or fallout, simply MUST HAVE in their collection. In fact, I daresay anyone who is into war games needs to have played this to experience the other side – no, not the opposing army’s, but the civilian side. Because so few war games ever bother to address *their* war as well – one for food, shelter and daily survival.

In This War of Mine, you take on the role of a handful of civilians who have banded together as residents of a bombed out multi-story apartment building to survive the war that has befallen their city of Pogoren, capital of the fictional republic of Graznavia, where vyseni rebels have taken control and seek to re-establish the former nation of Vysena, but find themselves surrounded by the Grazi army with all escape and supply route out of the city cut off by the military. As fighting and shelling is relentless during the day, only the night offers a chance for the besieged to leave their shelters and scavenge for supplies. Only one person at a time leaves the building each night to loot an increasing number of locations in the city that pop up on the map as the days pass. The other survivors guard the house until dawn, or sleep.

This game is therefore divided into a day mode and a night mode. During the day (6 AM to 8 PM equals about 7 in-game minutes), there are various things you can do in your building. Most important of which are to create specific work stations devoted to one particular thing, e.g. home improvement or tool manufacture. These allow you to access their build menus and then create further things in your building. From building additional furniture like stools to sit on, beds to sleep in, stoves to cook raw food into meals, radios to listen to the latest developments (weather, fighting, the rise and fall of prices for valuable commodities in the black market) and heaters to keep warm during winter, to reinforcing the shelter by boarding up the windows to lessen your chance of getting wounded by burglars and robbed of valuable resources.

As the game progresses, you will need to upgrade your stations so that you can build more complex work stations, like a place to collect rainwater, or brew moonshine, or catch mice, or grow herbs and vegetables, or another place to create medicine or roll those herbs into cigarettes that you can then trade in the black market for other supplies you need.

Meanwhile, the survivor you send out to loot each night has a fixed number of inventory slots he can fill upto a certain amount of one specific type of looted item as he combs the location for valuables. Every tool he takes with him occupies one such slot, but helps him out on that map. E.g. since your looter is on a timer (9 PM to 5 AM), a shovel will help him quickly dig through piles of rubble, a crowbar to (noisily) force doors and locks open, single-use lockpicks to do this quietly, or, unlike knives, the axe as a multi-purpose tool to chop down furniture into wood he can collect later – or people. 

Be warned through, that this game has a built in moral system – robbing or killing civilians will bring down the morale of all your survivors, down to the point of depression and even suicide. And getting hurt in combat requires expensive bandages to allow for the wounds to heal. So it is best to avoid it. The game therefore also has a nice stealth mechanism incorporated into it – you can hide in dark alleys to let potential enemies pass you. And should you get caught, the AI will generally warn you to leave, and if you comply, you can avoid confrontation. The AI is also smart enough to remember previous encounters (at least on the same night) so if you get caught a second time, they won’t be so forgiving. Running out of resources though will mean desperation can set in – and drive you to increasingly dire encounters with those who guard their valuables dearly.


DLC

This game has two separate DLCs which consist of The Little Ones and the Season Pass that contains three storydriven episodes (which you can  also buy individually). The DLCs also adds new locations to the game, although these locations have been made available for free even for people who don’t have the DLCs, in the form of the Final Cut update. 

The Little Ones adds additional characters in the form of children: survivors with initially very limited tasking abilities (such as shoveling snow, fetching a bottle of moonshine that has finished brewing or herbs that have finished growing) but with an aptitude for learning most household tasks grownups do, if the adults are willing to take the extra time to teach them. However, children have to play to be happy, and they will get sad quickly if they don’t. Each shelter initially starts with just one “game” that only the child can interact with, and doing so will make it play that game for 1 hour. You have the child construct additional games in the shelter, and playing 3 different games a day will lift the child’s sadness. When winter sets in, the buildable snowman outside that is pretty useless for adults serves as an additional game station for children once it is completed. 

Father’s Promise is the first of the three story driven DLCs and introduces you to the children mechanic, although not really, as it is heavily scripted and mostly involves the dad in a city-wide goose chase as he hunts for clues leading to the abduction of his child.

The Last Broadcast is a far more interesting DLC because for the first time in the game it introduces a disabled character, who is on crutches and can only hobble around and not even go downstairs. However, he has a caring wife who goes out each night to scavenge and brings back supplies and news for him to broadcast as a radio host. This story presents you with choices you have to make throughout the episode that have consequences: do you use your power as a radio broadcaster to “join” in the war and help rebels against the army? Or point civilians toward looting army supplies? Or fail to warn rebels of an impending army attack? 

Fading Embers is perhaps the most ambitious and expansive of all three story driven episodes as it is heavily focused on narration and even involves the survivors changing shelters to the largest shelter ever – an entire museum full of priceless historic artifacts that need to be secured while the war is raging on outside. But as winter sets in and wood starts running out, which priceless piece of history will you incinerate to survive for one more night? And to whom will you turn to, in order to save the rest of the collection from destruction?

Overall, this game is a gripping experience with a steep learning curve, and as you familiarize yourself with the city of Pogoren, and learn which things to build first, which locations to loot first, and which ones to avoid, over time you will transform from a starving, broken soul to a successful survivor even neighbors can depend on. Highly recommended!

The experience of this game is way too different from anything else I have ever played. It has this element of addiction that causes one to feel the need to take care of their characters' needs and wants in order for them to make it in this dangerous world of survival. The characters you play have emotions and can also get tired and hungry from all the salvaging and hunting or trading for food and medicine. Great planning needs to take place in order to delegate certain daily activities to the characters you have living together in a home such as; building equipment, guarding at night, cooking, trading etc. If this is not done correctly then you will run out of resources and have the characters die or simply leave, I once had a character so stressed about the stealing, hunger, killing, weather, and wounds that they just ended up committing suicide, that was when I got to know the magnitude of the game that this is no place to play. This game shows the impact of war on ordinary civilians who are trying to survive and make it through daily, and in doing so one can have an idea of how cruel the world would really get if we did live that kind of Call of Duty life that we so think we would be the gun-wielding heroes whereas we would actually be living this kind of hell. I never got to finish this game, I do not even know if there is an ending to it or a buildup to an end, so I just left the game because of how addictive it can get trying to grind and make things right by your characters or survivours just so they can have ONE good day, just ONE! 
I would gladly recommend this one.

¿cansado de juegos bélicos donde eres el soldado que más mata en una partida? ¿donde tienes armas y buena cantidad de munición y destruyes todo lo que tengas a tu paso? este juego es lo contrario.

This war of mine es una deconstrucción de los juegos bélicos pero en este caso se enfoca del lado de los sobrevivientes, el juego te hace una pregunta contundente ¿qué estas dispuesto a hacer para sobrevivir?

Eres parte del conflicto bélico, pero en este aso eres el civil, tienes a tu familia ¿qué haces para sobrevivir? - This war of mine no te dice que tienes que hacer, todo depende de tu moralidad (nada esta bien, nada esta mal). This war of mine no te cuestiona, te deja libre, solo... la decisión está en tus manos.

No es un juego divertido, en absoluto.
No lo recomiendo por ser divertido.

Nuestros personajes son personas y con ello todo lo que puede traer un ser humano (hambre, sed, emociones, situaciones, carácter). Cada uno con una historia personal. Las fotografías no son simples fotografías, No están muertas, pues cada uno de ellos te ven, te observan, parpadean, saben que están en un juego donde eres tú quien toma la decisión de que hacer con sus vidas. Al final eres responsable de que pasará cuando termine la guerra, si es que logras que ellos sobrevivan. 

Tendrás que tomar decisiones siempre. ¿ayudar a otros o cuidarme? ¿hacer una mesa de trabajo o cerrar las ventanas? ¿donas comida a un niño que la necesita  o comer un día más entre el grupo?

te hará sentir como una puta mierda por intentar sobrevivir a una guerra

90988624.review:
A game loosely based on the conflict in Donbass between the Ukrainian government and the Peoples Republics of Donetsk and Lugansk.

It covers the hardships and struggles of civilians living in war zones without presenting an excessive amount of bias on the "government" and "rebel" forces that are featured in the game. An argument could be made that the incidents of torture that occur by the soldiers but not the rebels could be anti-east bias and the roles would most likely be reversed if the game had taken place in a NATO aligned country.

In terms of actual game play they had a good balance of resource management, stealth, character development, with the opportunity for action and combat if that's the route you choose to go. The game is pretty replayable and the DLC stories offer some nice finite structure while keeping all the things that made the game good.

It's really good, really tense, and really difficult. Start hoarding that canned food for the winter, get at least two traps, a wood stove, and a planter as soon as possible.

90842370.review:
Un muy buen juego. Muy diferente de otros. Sencillo de jugar.
Te pone en la piel de un grupo de supervivientes durante la guerra de Bosnia en una ciudad.
Tienes que gestionar al grupo, los recursos y tu base. Saldras a explorar para recoger recursos. Los puedes ir construyendo o comerciando. Te veras afectado por las decisiones y acciones que tomes o hagas.
Es un juego algo triste y profundo. Realmente te mete en la historia. Tu objetivo es sobrevivir durante un determinado numero de dias.
Lo recomiendo.

90730251.review:
This game was okay, I beat it 3 times. The graphics are different and interesting. I really like the inventory management system. 
After a few playthroughs and knowing where everything is, for me there is no replay value. It will just sit in my library, and after sheer boredom will probably boot it up in a couple of years and play it for 2 hours then remove it. 
The game's generated randomness can be very unforgiving and not to your favor, resulting in GAME OVER. (I know it is supposed to simulate war in real life...). 
This game is VERY similar to another STEAM game called - 'Sheltered'. If I had to choose between the two for enjoyment and get my 'money's worth', I would pick 'Sheltered'. 
Once you get over the hump of overcoming the obstacles (collecting the needed resources to build) the game becomes very repetitive and loses enjoyment. Another situation what I did not like is the good/bad endings are solely based on trial and error. For ex. I was unaware that I had to keep a certain item in my inventory until a scenario popped up. 
If you are going to buy this game, I recommend DO NOT PAY FULL PRICE, or buy 'Sheltered' instead.

90693290.review:
I have to say this game is seriously lacking in depth. I found it incredibly repetitive and boring. Sleep, eat, look for more stuff to eat. There are so many games of this survival vein out there that have so much more to do in them. Compared to what's out there this game just didn't stack up for me.

Edit: I bucked up and played through an entire game, and I still stand by my review. The game was an incredibly repetitive, boring, and unrewarding experience. It has no depth, there's no interactions between characters except when they're depressed, the "story" is really weak and ends abruptly. The only things to do during the day are have your characters sit in a chair or sleep in a bed, and a few weak crafting interactions. The entire game is just getting food and supplies. During the day your people do fuck all, at night you send one out to raid places and find supplies. This experience just repeats until the game ends. It's not that difficult to keep your people alive, and the game does nothing to make you care about these people. Their stories are poorly written and because they don't interact with each other or do anything, you just really couldn't care less what happens to them. Its also a really slow game. It took me several hours of this boring rinse and repeat BS to beat a game and in the end it just felt empty and unrewarding. Wish I refunded lol

Overall I'm writing this one off as a waste of my money and yours.

Although I recommend this game, it is a 70-30 decision due to the game’s current state: 
[list][*] The visuals are fantastic. The artists did a very good job and the game looks amazing. 
[*] Overall the setting and the story/stories is good. Can be hard to say this for some of them but it is what it is. 

However since recent updates quite a few bugs and glitches were introduced that really ruin the experience: 
[*] The audio in the game is great but some of the sounds stack up on each other. The most noticeable one is the child crying and damn he/she cries a lot to the point that I had to turn off the sound completely since it was getting really irritating. 
[*] Some of the text might look [b][double/triple space][/b] like this, [b][capital letter after comma][/b] Especially in the [b][double/triple space][/b] campaign mode. (Okay, Steam hates it too, so I had to include the square brackets to explain what I mean :D)
[*] I used to play in English but at one point I switched to Russian and not only the above text errors were there but also some of the text was not translated even though Russian is considered as finished and fully implemented language in the game. 
[*] A few visual glitches, especially with the doors. Characters or some of their body parts would path through them. Looks really bad, especially if its in a cut scene. 
[*] I believe this is a minor programming error - if your character is standing on the right side from someone who you then click to speak to, the character would first, for some reason, walk to the left side of that person and then the dialogue would start. 
[*] Also when the above happens both of the characters might end up standing inside of each other and then the text would overlay, which not only makes it look weird but hard to read. 
[/list]
I would really appreciate if the developers gave the game one more final polish and also fixed the above things. 
Also would be really nice if they changed some of the icons, especially the one with the chair, since it always confuses me at the beginning of the game when my character doesnt loot the stuff but sits down on the chair :D

89918606.review:
We are talking about good people in the middle of war. They wont steal because they know the consequences of getting their own things stolen. They wont murder because they are in a bad situation exactly because of other people do it. And you cant be on a shelter with a murderer, or with a thieve. 
You cant lie, because thats not an option when you are seeking to survive and depend on the people that lives with you.

I think the game portaits perfectly the whole "being a civilian surviving in a city at war" picture. Random good people shoved together in a ruined house, because the option is a bullet in the head. All trying to keep alive while staying sane and healthy. You had a normal life 2 months ago, but now you dont have a choice.

When you are at war, you dont have much to get distracted. You dont have much to keep you from OVERTHINKING. All you think about is the war. And the thougth of stealing from someone as miserable as you can break your soul if you dont find a way to forget about it.

This game tries to show the other side of the those war games where you are the hero that brings death to your enemies without thinking twice, sometimes without even looking at your victim's face. This is a game about normal people, about emotions, about struggling to avoid death while surrounded by it. This is a game about suffering. 

To be in the situation where "You're starving. The kid is sick, and you have no meds", and you are facing the impossible choice, is exactly why you want to play this game. Do you become the vilain and steal, or even murder your neighbor? Someone who could have been your friend a couple of weeks ago? If you cant think of another option, then you will do it "because you have to"? 
The alternative is your own suffering and misery, so you have to decide. What do you choose? Will you become the monster who survives or the monster who let the kid die?

This is war.

89514174.review:
Sorry, but after spending a good amount of time, I cannot recommend this game. At first, I was actually finding this game to be pretty good, but then the massive flaws starts showing up and really dragged this game down way too much.
1) The game is buggy. I found a good number of items disappearing from scavanging spots I dropped my stuff off when I find something I need more of during revisits, especially when I come back in the very next day and there are no NPCs in said area.  
2) Melee combat does not work whatsoever. Even if you have a good melee weapon and need to take out an enemy, almost all the time you try to engage in melee combat, the enemy will almost always be the one to successfully attack your character. Especially in parts where there is no hiding spots and/or if you ran out of ammo and need to resort to melee combat. 
3) The cover is pretty awkward at times. If you step out of cover, you have to move around before you can get back into the same cover. Getting back into the same spot from where you exit doesn't work. Tried it a couple of times during a lot of my failed attempts (mostly due how awful the melee combat is), and never worked. It gets pretty bad when you sneak attack and kill an enemy, and sometimes that triggers the others to come up after you, and trying to get back into cover like this will take a bit more time, when time is sometimes what you don't have. 
4) The game is way too slow. There is no speed up option to make the day go any faster, meaning you have to wait forever for the clock to run out as you wait for whoever that is working on something to get their job finished. It gets even worse if you have to restart the same day with a lot of things you have to redo again, mainly cause of failed attempts, meaning you have to wait for the game to drag on even longer just so you can wait for the night and whatnot.

89404350.review:
This one is a very soft yes as I am really on the fence about it. The artwork and styling is gorgeous. The characters are interesting. The game mechanics are somewhat difficult to learn. The premise is original. And it actually becomes pretty fun once you know what you're doing. Save for a small number of very annoying problems, I'd absolutely recommend this game.

Let's start with the time efficiency problem. Suppose you have your characters working on something in the shelter. You want to complete that task and then start the next one? Sit there and wait and watch them work as there is no fast-forward option. You have only the "End Day" button. The game would be unplayable without this. But even still, it's a frustrating waste of time to sit around waiting. This complaint matters a lot more once you've learned the game and want to play through all the scenarios quickly, especially if you don't have much time to game. There is simply too much time wasted waiting around staring at your monitor.

Speaking of the "End Day" button, it's conveniently located next to the "our stuff" button. Mis-click? Too bad, it doesn't ask for confirmation. Close the game, re-load, and re-do the whole day.

Also annoying is that there is no built-in game save feature. I know they didn't want the player to defeat the RNG and simply re-roll when something happens that they don't like. I appreciate that as I like playing games the way they were meant to be played - bad things happen and you have to deal with them. But, back to the efficiency point. I'd love the feature to simply save the game at any point and return to it at that point instead of being forced to play through the whole in-game day and night. Also, it could allow you to have a few different games in parallel.

Final critical points. 1) Can't change keybinds and M1 and M2 do the same action. Why on earth wouldn't you split these up??? Can't say how many times I've tried panning the camera with M2 only to accidentally move a character to the wrong place. 2) Character pathing. "I don't know how to get there." What? But you know how to run to the exit across the whole map! Also, you were just there! Also, when you do know how to get there, why are you running into the locked door instead of going around?

These complaints are from the perspective of someone who doesn't have that much time to play games. So when I do, I don't want to spend a lot of time waiting around. I actually really liked this game but these few problems almost made me not recommend it.

88785959.review:
I have only played this game 11 hours or so, but I have to say that it is one of the most unusual gaming experiences I've ever had. It is extremely bleak, difficult, dark, and engaging.  The reason I have not played it more is that I lose a lot. I'm crap at this game, and I don't want to go read a guide about it, because I'm still intrigued about learning the game. 

So why haven't I played more often? When you lose, you have not just died yourself like in most games, but your whole group has died. One. By. One. It is just brutal to lose this game. The developers have truly created not only an atmosphere (which is noteworthy, detailed and lit with artistic sensibility), but you get character development and story beats that are absorbing and emotionally affecting. It is highly stylized realism. I cannot say enough about these elements of the game. Simply brilliant.

The mechanics and game play are excellent. everything works, and there are no boring chores. Crafting makes sense, and it is not simple. The levels of realism in the game do not make it boring or plodding.  Things happen at a perfect pace.  The various missions and the map are intriguing and varied, so there is never a sense that they have re-purposed a previous level or model. Excellent craftsmanship, all around.

I had no technical problems in the game. Everything worked as expected, and the visuals are great, but do not seem to burden a system set up for gaming (mine is modest, not top of the line).  This is not an action game, so I would warn off those looking for a lot of fighting or shooting. There are good stealth elements in it, however.  

I would highly recommend this game.

88451718.review: The game presents a perspective and view on war that we often don't get, and as such I think it is an extremely valuable work to have out there. It presents that there is more to war than two armies fighting, that most people would rather not be in the war in the first place. It also presents moral and ethical issues, how far would you go to try to survive, and is it worth that cost? The game hits hard with the emotions, the injustice, the desperation. The depth and importance of this game strikes home even more when you consider that this isn't merely fiction, and it doesn't romanticize war like so many works do, its based upon real war and realistic events like what occurred in the Siege of Sarajevo. The game gives us a valuable perspective on the nature of war and on history that many people probably arent aware of. That we can learn from it, give some context and feeling to things that happen in the real world through a game... I can't emphasize how significant that feels.

88226757.review:
[b]Gameplay: 6/10[/b]
[b]Story: 5/10[/b]
[b]Social: -/10[/b]
[b]Graphic and Animation: 6/10[/b]
[b]Audio: 6/10[/b]

Note: This review is my personal take on the game. I'm not a certified critic (if such a thing even exists), I'm just a fellow gamer who happens to enjoy writing and evaluating my games.
[hr][/hr]

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
[b]6/10[/b]

This War of Mine presented a survival simulation of citizens who were stuck in the middle of a civil war in a city called Pagoren. Players take control of one or more characters, each with their own attributes. The game difficulty depends on the composition of your party, you can choose a default composition from the game or create your custom group. The game can be quite challenging at first but once you're introduced to all the elements, it becomes a boring repetition. Is it worth the money though? Yes, you can clear your first playthrough in under 4 hours and I played for 56 hours before uninstalling the game.

[h1]Story[/h1]
[b]5/10[/b]

You get to piece information together figuring out what is happening in this world, it's not a mindblowing mystery, just common tragedy humankind repeated over centuries. The characters have their own background/lore/personality which gives life to the decision you make, some get sad when you kill, some just shrug it off.

[h1]Social[/h1]
[b]-/10[/b]

No co-op or any multiplayer feature.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
[b]6/10[/b]

The graphic styles and designs are spot on with the setting of the game, it adds a layer to the aesthetic and immerses the world, even more, painting the torn city of the bitterness that is war. The use of pencil sketch style and the almost monochrome color made everything so much better. It's a small but smart addition.

[h1]Audio[/h1]
[b]6/10[/b]

The game's music and sound effects were pleasant but nothing to write home about. Throughout my gameplay, I did not experience any disconnection or sounds that don't belong to an object or action.

87837824.review:
In war-torn [insert Eastern European country], three survivors banded together to endure the borderline post-apocalyptic circumstances they found themselves in: Pavle, Bruno, and Marcos. Marcos was the pro scavenger, specialising in the unique skill of opening cabinet doors slightly faster than his mates.  

Things were going really swell. Resistance appeared minimal, supplies kept flooding in. They were going to make it....

...but see, Marcos got greedy. He started robbing homeless people blind after his discovery of a pistol and 18 bullets made him the ultimate apex predator. And, well, life has a sense of humour because it was at the Church that Marcos encountered not Bible thumpers to rob, but a pack of angry gangsters. See, Marcos excelled at opening cabinets, but he never did too well at Hide and Seek.

Marcos....did not make it. Despair haunted Pavle and Bruno in the aftermath of Marcos' death....until one day, a fellow citizen named Katia appeared before their doorstep, asking to join up. Hope endured.

But there's no such thing as a free lunch. Katia had to earn her keep. Her initiation task? Retrieve Marcos' equipment at the Church and avenge his death. 

To her credit, Katia lasted a good 10 seconds longer against the thugs than Marcos did.

87729098.review:
He recibido este juego en otro bundle de claves aleatorias.

Y para provenir de uno de estos paquetes, puedo considerarme afortunado; ya que no es el típico juego indie que te suelen clavar, y que tras probarlo un par de veces acaba en el olvido. Este es un juego muy interesante.

Es una propuesta de supervivencia en 2D, con unos escenarios muy cuidados, una mecánica sencilla y agradable, y una trama soberbia. Además, está perfectamente doblado al castellano.

En This War of Mine tomamos el control de un grupo de supervivientes bélicos. Nada de soldados, aquí nos encontramos con civiles que viven la funesta y luctuosa consecuencia de una guerra que azota su ciudad. Una ciudad que lógicamente está asolada, y los civiles se encuentran a la merced de sus habilidades para rebuscar en escombros y proveerse de víveres y otros útiles que les permitan seguir sufriendo una mañana más, con la esperanza de hallar un futuro menos funebérrimo.

Según van sucediéndose las jornadas, vamos encontrando nuevos retos, sobre todo por las noches, que tenemos que abandonar nuestro ya de por sí lamentable refugio, para tratar de rapiñar en otras propiedades colindantes, y enfrentarnos a situaciones desconocidas, como pudieran ser otros civiles hostiles, o incluso con soldados.

La banda sonora y los efectos son muy adecuados, y otorgan al juego una seriedad máxima. Está muy cuidado en todos los aspectos, y creo que en general, esta aventura hará las delicias de todos los aficionados a la estrategia, supervivencia y a las buenas tramas e historias. Además, el juego tiene una extensa sección de workshops, donde se pueden encontrar historias alternativas que agrandan su jugabilidad.

Reitero que al venir de un bundle de claves aleatorias, ha sido un juego que me ha sorprendido para bien. No sé si merecerá la pena pagar lo que piden por él, pero si se puede adquirir de oferta y te gustan los géneros descritos, es una opción muy a tener en cuenta.

Con todo esto, no puedo más que recomendarlo.

A mandar

87619455.review:
Overly philosophic game reviews: This War of Mine

One of my all time favourites. Excellent atmosphere and engaging survival mechanics aside, TWOM excels at capturing the fragility of morals in a war zone. Are you starving, cold, and dying on the inside? You can do the right thing, stick it out, and feel stronger in the long run. Or you can succumb to instant gratification, prey on those who are weaker than you, and gradually succumb to your own conscience. A great example of art imitating life. 

I recommend this game to players who enjoy survival games where choice is an integral part of game play.

I had some doubts before playing this game and thought it was a bit complicated. The game itself is rather nice to learn and fun to play out. 

Pros:
-Interesting NPCs and interactions. 
-Emotional downfalls and impacts when it comes to certain decisions or taking a life.
-Survival in which heat, shelter, food, and medicine are crucial.
-Great graphics. Very gritty and represents a solid image of surviving during a war.
-Intriguing stories and dlcs. There are also custom stories you can download from workshop for additional gameplay and fun plots.
-Alternate endings and not just one linear storyline.

Cons:
-A few bugs here and there. Funniest one is when your character gets hit and phases through a grate. 
-A bit of slow interactions or no interactions when clicking a few times. Kind of a pain when it comes to tense situations or danger ones.
-A few more ideas to throw in this game would be nice. Always pained me how we cannot throw things to distract someone or find ways to create noise to divert attention.

87106272.review: Maybe I'm misremembering, but I remember this game being more bleak and depressing than it is now. I don't remember 'escape' being an option back in the day. In any case, the scenarios are great. I understand they are meant to make you sympathize with the plight of people stuck in a warzone. I found the museum scenario to be the best at that because there are quite a few moral conundrums which appear which don't have immediate answers. Unless you don't care about the historical artifacts of the made-up country in which case I imagine at least one was much easier to make. But in all seriousness, it's a fairly bleak and serious game which I enjoy immensely for the atmosphere it creates and the hard problem solving of the actual gameplay and exploration.

First of all,there's a question I wanna ask.

[h1] Will you kill your old neighbor just because you're in lack of supplies?[/h1] 

You probably gonna say No.

Because you dont need to worry about it now,you're living in a peaceful country and you dont need to worry about if there's a guy with guns that breaks into your house and kill your love ones.

[h1]But,is that really ture?[/h1]

No is not.

Conflicts are never seems to be stopped for thousands of years,when there's is a disagreement between two countries,there probably a war.Thousands of years,the war never changed.From the Western Europe to the Middle East,from the middle age to the modern warfare.

Children in some Middle East countries cant even get a good sleep or just a cup of clean water.Nobody help them when their friends get shot,nobody help them when their home was destroyed last night.

But what can they do?Only to live.They need to leave the home they live for many years and travel thousands miles to get to the safe zones just because they dont wanna get killed.

They are just innocent,they are not meant to die,they dont deserve it,it's not the way their lives should be,if there's no war,they probably gonna live just like us,dont need to think about food,water and shelter.They can go to school,play with their best friends,dont need to worry if there is an air strike that can destroy their homes in the midnight.

Things are different when in different situations.You dont need to feel sorry if you robbed somebody or killed someone just wanna to get some supplies,cause this is just a game,you just wanna live and you dont need to kill a real person.

In the game,war will continue for 60 days at most.But in real life,the Siege of Sarajevo continues for more than 4 years.It becomes the largest city-siege war after WWII,3 times longer than Battle of Stalingrad,and about 5000 civilian were killed in the siege.

After knowing this,will you still say No for the beginning question?

Everyone wants to be a good person,no one wants to hurt others,but if you're a father,your son is dying,he needs to be treated ASAP,will you still hold your line and not rob the neighbor？In war zones,will you lie to others only to get a ticket for escape？

[h1]Hope there is no more wars or kill,PEACE[/h1]
