86424930.review:
NOTE: I recommend playing this game without any walkthroughs; they will just ruin your gaming experience.

This War of Mine is a great game that tells the story of survivors, mere civilians, caught in somebody else's war and just trying to survive. This is a simple survival/crafting game that keeps on giving even after you have mastered it.

Much has already been said by others about the mechanics of the game so, while I will touch a little bit on that topic, I will mostly focus on the storytelling.

To start with: the stories in the game leave a bit to be desired. All the characters are stock, with stock storylines. However, when I first opened the game up, I was still amazed at THIS story, the story that I was playing through!

When people say that decisions matter in a game, they usually are referring to branching storylines, but in TWoM, there is only one storyline - the one you are playing. (In fact, until the DLC, there wasn't even any alternate win-conditions! You just had to survive until the end of each group's story.)

So, when I say "choices matter" in this game, I mean your day-to-day, moment-to-moment choices have an impact on the experiences of your survivors. Do you help your neighbors or let them die for lack of resources? Do you help the hoodlums looting abandoned buildings or let them go their way? How will your characters feel about those choices? Will they be content with their humanitarian efforts, or will they become depressed because they are callously adding to the devastation around them? (Each choice can sometimes lead you down a path, also; if you make a shady choice, you may be asked to make even shadier choices, until eventually you realize that you are no longer the Good Guy.)

Whenever you do/not do a humane deed, you will suffer a morale bonus/penalty, so if you are looking for a game without consequences, this one isn't it. This one preaches at you that you must be a good person.

The mechanics are stupid-easy; use your left mouse to go places and do things, use your right mouse button to go and do faster. Collect, build, produce, trade. Survive. Win. At first, until I understood how the game worked, survival was somewhat challenging; now? Not so much.

On the other hand, the entire game is constantly busy telling you, "War is bad, mmkay?" And, about the time that I could play the game with my eyes closed, I realized something else: I knew exactly which people to help (because they would return the favor,) and which to leave behind (because they either wouldn't help me back, or they wouldn't penalize me for not helping.) I knew which tools to take to which locations to maximize my looting time. I knew how to optimize my trades. I knew how to create a comfortable economy, and how to make the right weapons, and which weapons to sell and which to use. I knew when to be peaceful for maximum benefit and when it was okay to kill. I also knew how to get my spirits up after I had done so. I knew how to ignore This War of Mine.

The final treat in this game is the realization that I have become inured to This War of Mine, and while I still return to the game over and over, I have become desensitized to the human suffering that exists all around me in the game. I took this gaming experience and tried to look at the Real World through its lens, and now I am faced with a choice in the Real World: Do I become desensitized and cynical, or do I keep trying to help the people around me with the little bit that I have been blessed with?

Even though I (arguably) have mastered this game, it is still preaching to me and teaching me things I need to think about.

I'm rating "This War of Mine" positively, although I'm not entirely happy. The game is pretty different from everything else that I've played but I got bored/irritated quite a few times. One of my critique points is that the game doesn't really try and help you understand the game mechanics and the impacts of decisions. But this might be an analogy for "When you're surviving in the middle of a war as a civilian you're also improvising as you go". Maybe the intention is indeed to give you this sense of helplessness.

I haven't finished any playthrough because there comes a point where the risk becomes increasingly high and you kind of run out of interesting things to do. I think the game could do with some usability improvements to make it more pleasant to play. But the core idea is pretty cool.

It's also interesting to note how some of the mechanics ended up being used in the later "Frostpunk" (Which in my opinion is way better in all aspects, but is admittingly a completely different genre).

I'm giving it a thumbs up for creativity and core gameplay, but it gets repetitive/annoying fast.

86008186.review:
Even though I felt like I already knew everything in the game from watching streamers play it back around 2015 for hours on end, it still felt very satisfying to buy and play it myself now years later. It was nostalgic and that gave it value yes, but what's really meaningful in this game is not the content to explore but the feeling and emotions there are to it. 

You don't control a bunch of fighters, but just normal people trying to survive while war rages on. You cook, sleep, keep your shelter up, and get ready for the night by day. If you have time you might want to try playing the guitar or build a snowman to keep the spirits up. By night you choose one character to go out and scavenge with and hope that you prepared the others so that they are able to defend your home from bandits. 

If it gets too cold you'll get sick and die, if you get hit you'll bleed and die, if you don't have food you'll starve and die, if you don't sleep enough you'll get weak and die, and if one character does poorly others will get stressed and unhappy. 

The game is not perfect and it doesn't have super deep mechanics, but everything there is works very well together. There is a danger to a game like this to have too much stuff to do, making it confusing for a starter. But I don't feel like This War of Mine has that problem. There could be more to it though, but it's definitely not too little either. Even though I knew most of the maps and characters by heart I still spent +25 hours playing just the core game and having fun right after buying it.

There is Stories (DLC) that I didn't even touch yet (even though I bought it too), which I feel can only make the game better with the extra play value it offers. Even if the stories would turn out to be a weak addition, the core game is good enough alone to be well worth buying This War of Mine.

I hated having kids in the game (Little Ones DLC). They make it so hard and annoying sometimes. But at the same time they do add to the realism of the game. And while I cursed them for making the game more difficult in a way I disliked, I still do enjoy a good challenge.


Bonus points if you like:
- micro management games
- dark & moody games
- difficult games

Stuff some people might not enjoy:
- trying to go slow and steady, playing "just to survive"
- your characters dying off for good
- stress


Core game is excellent. Haven't really tried out Stories. Little ones is 50/50.

Ask me anything! I answer to comments, accept friend requests and am up for discussion.

85852449.review:
I'm really on the fence about this, and if this was a question of stars rather than the binary yes/no I would probably still give it six or seven. But I just cannot recommend it. 

It is actually a solid game. You search for resources in a great variety of detailed and unique settings, and use those to build up your home in a way that'll help you survive the war. There's a lot of freedom in how you do this, and a lot of flexibility. That's great.

The art style is really fitting, and very tasteful. It's grim without being dark, it's busy without being cluttered, and it's simple without being dull. Honestly, presentation is 10/10. 

But where it falls down, for me, is when the game starts to punish you for playing in a way that is seen as immoral. Here's how it works:
You have a shelter, three adults and a kid. You're starving. The kid is sick, and you have no meds. All the safe places have been picked clean, and you're faced with a choice: You can go and risk scavenging in an extremely dangerous area where there's a good chance you'll die way before you find food or meds. You can go and try to rob a few thugs and probably get your shit wrecked in the process, or you can sneak into a rich house and steal some of their shit. Guess which choice the game punishes?

Yup, stealing. A minority of characters are OK with it, but the majority will get sad and eventually depressed if you steal or murder, which makes them sleep badly, refuse to work, or just leave one night. This is annoying for a few reasons:

-NPC's are always more important than the more moral PCs. Doesn't matter how tough things are, stealing is never OK, and boy does the game shove this down your throat with little speech boxes appearing every two minutes where the guy is ruminating on how terrible your choice was. 'Did we really need to steal from those poor people?' YES, the kid is seriously ill and we have no food. YES we needed to steal. Next time we'll just eat your sanctimonious ass. 

-The aforementioned sadness mechanic. There are a whole list of things that can increase PC sadness, but very little that can decrease it. Being well fed and warm isnt enough to make your guys 'content', they also need to be helping other people every couple of days. Meanwhile, steal one can of meat and WHAT HAVE WE BECOME??

-Finally, why is my guy always going back to the shelter in the morning and just telling everyone that he brained some crazy old guy with a crowbar to steal his meds? He went out alone, he came back alone with a bag of goodies. At least give me the option to lie to the other folk and maybe avoid the sadness.

So that's why I can't recommend this game; they want you to play a game set in a besieged, war torn city in the depths of winter, with a collection of people who have had their families and homes torn apart, but they want you to retain the moral standards of a wealthy, church going suburban American family. Thou shalt not kill, thou shalt not steal, thou shalt not play this game any way that would upset the developers. 

Oh and if someone dies because you didn't steal those meds, guess what? Everyone gets depressed anyway. Fuckin...

85556832.review:
If we can classify a game as “important”, this is definitely one of them.

A great survival perspective from a civilian’s POV, in a besieged city during a civil war, where your choices will impact their lives drastically. Will you hold on to your humanitarian values and help those in need or pursue survival at all costs, facing its’ horrors and moral implications? There aren’t right answers. Wrong things don’t happen to good or bad people, they happen to people who did the wrong thing at the wrong time. Even if you think you’re getting the hang of things and actually have supplies and food, the game reminds you that war and its cruelty will get you no matter how much you plan or organize. It can and will break your soul to the point where, even if survival is possible, it’s not wanted anymore.

I found myself emotionally exhausted after finishing each game, which I see as an incredible achievement from the developers. Your play through will stay with you even after you’ve turned off the game hours ago, as survival is of upmost importance and seeing your characters not make it is heartbreaking. The way their faces look so real and their eyes close when they pass away is gut wrenching, as we see them as real people who we failed.

The Little Ones DLC adds to the challenge as children are now involved. They won’t naturally know how to do most things and you can teach them while also spending time playing with them, since their happiness and spirit also affect the rest of the team. It’s a constant battle to maintain the little innocence they have left while living in an active war zone, their memories and thoughts being of better times in the past.

The stunning artwork and soundtrack lift this game to another level, as despair isn’t only conveyed by your actions but also through the existing atmosphere. A low saturated world where happiness feels like a foreign thought, listening to depressing and revenge anthems whilst trying to live just another day.

Immense replayability with different scenarios, characters and traits. Simple game mechanics for any type of player. High recommendation for its loud meaningful message.

85256639.review: One of my favorite survival strategy games, it's very much a war simulator from the civilian perspective. Choices matter and a lot of them balance morality and pragmatism, with the civilian characters having individualized perspectives and responses to the choices. (I've played this game a bunch on Xbox as well, my total playtime is probably in the 50-75 hr range)

85242871.review:
Great concept.  Mediocre Execution.  It is like a gorgeously presented plate of food with no flavor.  The stark, oppressive, and at times depressing atmosphere is just that: An unending Stark, oppressive and depressing backdrop with no relief in sight.  I am a vet.  I have been deployed in hostile fire zones, peacekeeper missions, and relief work from Africa to former Yugoslavia and no matter what,  in all of those situations, there are occasional moments laughter and fun.  I get the serious nature of this subject matter, but Holy Hell!  I would slit my own throat to avoid the grind of these poor fools.  Which brings me to the game.  Tedious is the one word I would use to describe it.  I could not really connect to ant of the characters, since they have ZERO personality.  An occasional voice over narrative would have been nice and enhanced the atmosphere and helped me connect to otherwise 2 dimensional characters.  They don't really connect to each other either.  There is minimal conversation between them and they blunder through their day without so much as a good morning to their fellow companions.  A radio voice would have been nice as well.  Neither of these added features would have been too costly for game developers.  Character's skills (most of which are useless anyway) did not seem to factor, nor can they get "better" at any skills which is not true to real life or game life at all. There was no option to negotiate out of combat - NPC's just see you and start firing.  If you kill, your companions are sad, even when you kill in self defence.   You will be raided about every third night... even if you have an armed guard because yes, they suck.    I could not get invested in the bland, inept characters at all.  
Not being invested in them worked out though.  Because some or all of your people will die.  Always.  Mostly out of your control and it vexed me quite a bit.  Many die in wars and conflicts.  I get that.  But this is a game and I just couldn't enjoy it.  Many do obviously.  I just felt with one or two more tweeks, this could have been a great game.  As it is I cannot recommend.  If you do play, Stock up on weapons, kill everyone for whatever you want, and wait for the ceasefire.  While your companions will be "sad" they will also be alive.

85223517.review: Great game. A lot of emotion for such a simple game.

85206191.review: This game has a lot going for it. It combines a post-apocalyptic survival game with resource management, and it is very fun, albeit rather bleak as well. I enjoy it because there is a lot of content and many options for any given play-through.

85183395.review: Evocative atmospherics and gut-punching storytelling will pull you into the lives and stories of people caught in a war-torn city. War rages all around you, and it will take keen planning just to survive.

85118303.review: Forced a crippled man to mine rubble with a pick-axe, sent his wife to die in a raging gun battle and then he commited suicide. Best sitcom i have watched in ages!

85089005.review: This can be a bit grindy, but once you get the hang of the game, it has a strange peaceful vibe. I typically play after I've smoked a bowl and its a great low-impact game to chill on.
